dialogues.text: A nice, orderly tract of post-World War II housing. Ident rows of little yards. Young MOMS. Scampering KIDS. Then, a SUBTITLE: "TEN YEARS EARLIER" 2.

dialogues.text: CU on two concerned eyes. The same eyes as the paintings. REVEAL they belong to a real girl: JANE, 8. She sits in h small house -- a typical young family's, spare and underfurnished. Suddenly -- Jane's mother MARGARET ULBRICH, 28, rushes th frame. Margaret is blonde, yearning, fragile. Terribly upset, she is hurriedly packing. Margaret throws her clothes in a suitcase. She shoves Jane's clothes and toys into another. Margaret barrels through the breakfast nook, which is a m art studio -- easel, canvases, paints. She scoops up her supplies. Margaret runs to the door -- then turns. The hallway is l with her PAINTINGS. Oils and inks of wide-eyed Jane, who grows from baby to toddler to child. Hastily, Margaret ta them down, each frame leaving an empty mark on the flower wallpaper. Finally she reaches the last spot -- a WEDDING PHOTO: Margaret and her HUSBAND, smiling, happy. Margaret peers -- then leaves it hanging. The door SLAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars roar down an interstate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret grips the wheel, uncertain. Jane stares. The car all loaded up. REFLECTIONS of passing BILLBOARDS drift ac the windshield. Images of perky, happy-fake Americans. Margaret bites her lip. Has she made the right decision..

dialogues.speaker: EST. SAN FRANCISCO
dialogues.text: San Francisco, 1958! A mix of SKYLINES and STOCK FOOTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weathered building: "G & B FURNITURE SUPPLY." Marga in the Packard, fixing her lipstick. Jane holds the "WANT ADS," a few circled. Margaret gets out and straightens he skirt. Jane smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck. 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beaten industrial office. Margaret sits anxiously, watc the BOSS, a tired guy in a cheap suit. He glowers unsurel her JOB APPLICATION. Scratching his face. Hmmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't get many ladies in here. So your husband approves of you working?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet; a soft Southern lilt) My husband and I are separated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Separated"? A deadly silence. He squirms uncomfortably. She presses on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I realize I have no employment experience... but I sure need this job. I have a daughter to support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not very good at tooting my own horn... but I love to paint, and if I could just show you my portfolio... He is baffled. Margaret pulls out a large ARTIST'S PORTFO She opens it, riffling through the pictures...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I studied at the Watkins Art Institute in Nashville, then took Illustration classes in New York. Here's a pastel I did... here's some fashion design... a portrait in charcoal... though I enjoy mixing mediums, preferably oil and ink... She's alive, enthused. The guy shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do understand this is a furniture company?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: A strained smile. 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret works on an enamel baby crib. Under stenciled "Humpty Dumpty," she quickly paints on a cartoonish egg m We WIDEN, revealing ten identical, completed cribs behind We WIDEN again -- revealing a DOZEN PAINTERS. All surroun by identical cribs. All painting identical Humpty Dumpty'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NORTH BEACH! An exotica of Beatniks, palm readers, interracial couples and coffeehouses. Ground zero for the Avant Garde. Margaret waits on a busy corner, a bit dazed peering at the parade of fun-loving Hipsters. Primly, she fixes herself. Margaret turns -- and suddenly grins. Running up is DEE-A 30, a Beat girl in a black leotard and sandals. Dee-Ann excitedly grabs her, and they laugh and hug girlishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar, you made it! You're in North Beach!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deirdre, look at you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dee-Ann."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dee-Ann"?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. But I hit this scene... and "Deirdre" just sounded like something my mother would call me. Margaret giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you flipping for all this?! Are you settled? How's Jane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane -- is swell. She's started in a sweet little school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though... it's hard without her father. I'm not sure we can do this... The thought hangs, and Margaret gets emotional. Teary-eye 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh stop that. You're better off. Between us, I never liked Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were a bridesmaid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. That's why I couldn't speak up. But if I ever see you wrong off again, I will tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now come on. Let's have some fun. WIDE - They start WALKING. Dee-Ann gestures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toss off your middle-class preconceptions! This is Pompeii! We're livin' in the volcano!! For jazz, check up the hungry i. For Italian, Vanessi's. For salvation, try the Buddhist temple. For art, the Six Gallery -- They pass a GALLERY. The displays are stark, Calder-like MOBILES and found-object SCULPTURES. Margaret stares, uns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they only show Modern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone only shows Modern!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the basement, they've got espresso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's espresso?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that like reefer? Dee-Ann LAUGHS, astounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a lot to learn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Sunday ART SHOW. It's picturesque, amateur ARTISTS displaying their paintings, jewelry, sculpture... The modern stalls are crowded with trendy BOHEMIANS. Abst lines, speckles of color. We drift away... and find Marga alone in her stall with Jane. Margaret sits patiently, surrounded by Big Eye paintings and charcoal portraits. I contrast with the neighbors, her work seems... quaint. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pink, chubby TOURIST FAMILY ambles over. Margaret brigh hopefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your stuff is cute. How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today's a special: Two dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you one. Beat -- then she nods, agreeing. She gestures. The little BOY sits. Margaret clips a fresh sheet of pape sharpens her charcoal... and... goes motionless. Studying boy's face. He gazes back. Then -- inspired, she begins sketching his EYES. Large an exaggerated. Then she fills in the shape of his head. His ears. His jaw. In a rush, his likeness appears. The parents come over to peek -- then gasp. Margaret is good. She sketches faster. Focused. Until a LOUD, PLUMMY VOICE drifts in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monet? "Monet"?! Whew -- that's a hell of a compliment. Though, if I may respectfully disagree, I'm more in the tradition of Pissarro. Margaret looks up, distracted. She resumes her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, get closer. Closer! Look at that sunlight coming through the mottled leaves. That's a bold yellow! Curious, Margaret casually peers over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding court in another booth is WALTER KEANE, 40. Walte astonishing: Hugely confident. Charming. Waggishly handsome. And dressed like an "Artist" -- striped turtlen with hands full of brushes. Walter's stall is filled with oils of Paris street scenes casually flirts with TWO YOUNG COEDS. They admire a paint

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna touch it? Do it! I lay it on thick -- you're not gonna break it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I poured myself into that painting. It's thirty-five dollars. 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter glances over -- and notices Margaret watching him. Shy, she quickly turns away, back to her portrait. Walter smiles rakishly. He's found a new interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter strides up to Margaret. She peers nervously... try to ignore him. She sketches faster. Shading... Walter watches. Admiring... and discreetly smelling her h Margaret pays no attention. Done, she blows into a can of It. Poosh! A fine mist sprays, setting the portrait. Without fanfare, she humbly turns the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All finished. Her customers gape, impressed. She smiles. The guy counts out four quarters, then happily leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET AND WALTER
dialogues.text: are left together. An unspoken frisson, until --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're better than spare change. You shouldn't sell yourself so cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just glad they liked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh! You're past that point! Your heart is in your work... He leans in, too close. Margaret shivers. Breathing faste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M-Margaret... Mmm. He grins, checking her out... her loose sexy blouse tight black capris. She flushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you rather flirt with those dolls over there? 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you, Margaret... He zeroes in on the artworks' signature: "M. Ulbrich"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Ulbrich."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Margaret Ulbrich, you're undervaluing yourself. Lemme show you how it's done. Walter spins to Jane. He SHOUTS out, like a carnival bark

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Girl! How would you like your portrait sketched by the World- Renowned Margaret Ulbrich?! Queen of the Bay! In mere minutes, she will capture your soul! Hm. Jane shrugs, unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Nah"?! (he grabs a PAINTING) Don't you wish this were you in this beautiful painting??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that IS me! And that's me... (she POINTS all over) And that one started as me, but then Mother turned it into a Chinese boy. Huh? Walter peers at Jane... then at Margaret. And then - it hits him. He grimaces, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're Mommy! My apologies, Honey. I misconstrued the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'll just mosey along, before Mr. Ulbrich comes back and socks me in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gut decision. She stares at Walter, then smiles slyly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ulbrich is out of the picture...! 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face slowly lights up. Ah! Sun breaking through cloud

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enchanting bistro. Wine barrels, laughing, twinkly tiv lights. Perfection. Walter flamboyantly enters, escorting Margaret. Instantly, the STAFF ERUPTS in excitement: "Monsieur Keane! Ah, Monsieur Keane is here! Bonsoir!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonsoir, gang! Henri! Sorry I didn't call first. Est-ce que tout va bien?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Je vais bien, merci! Comment allez- vous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Je vais bien! I'm with a beautiful woman! Could life be any grander?? They get led in. Margaret is dazzled. Walter whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't even have to pay! I'm set because I gave the chef a painting. You know what he said? "Nobody paints Montmartre like Walter Keane!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret and Walter enjoy an intimate dinner. The wine fl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you lived in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best time of my life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never even been on an airplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you have to experience these things! Grab 'em!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to be an artist, so I just went! Studied painting at the Beaux- Arts. Lived in a Left Bank studio. I survived on bread and wine... 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right! A wistful shrug. He chugs his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, walkin' away from the bourgeois scene wasn't a snap. I had to quit my job. Leave my wife. These choices aren't easy... She stares at her wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never acted freely. I was the daughter. The wife. The mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All my paintings are of Jane, because she's all I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't knock your work. I'd give an eyetooth to have your talent. Margaret is taken aback. He's absolutely sincere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can look into someone and capture them on canvas! You paint people! (he gestures sadly) I can only paint -- things. My street scenes are charming... but at the end of the day, it's just a collection of sidewalks and buildings. Walter goes silent. He has revealed his fears.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: She doesn't know what to say. Gently, she takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, I'd bet you could paint anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew... Baby, when you look at me like that, I could fall hard. Margaret gulps. Afraid to talk. 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is moving fast. You're my first date in a long time... Neither of them speaks. The tension builds -- There is a spark between them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lush green knoll, overlooking the park. Margaret and Wa have set-up TWO EASELS. They both smoke cigarettes. Marga is spattered with paint, stirring colors. Walter paces ab framing the scene with his fingers. Jane sits in front of them, playing paddleball. Bonk! Bon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetie, could you stop fidgeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, after all this time, you MUST know what my face looks like. Margaret winces. Walter laughs. She gets busy, penciling LARGE OVAL EYES. Then -- quick marks for the mouth and no Impatient, Jane spies on Walter's canvas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Your canvas is blank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er, you can't rush inspiration --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane! Don't bother Mr. Keane. You know creativity has to well up from the inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. She's not bothering me...! Walter leaves Jane. He points at Margaret's canvas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something I gotta ask you. What's with the big crazy eyes...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe things can be seen in eyes. They're the windows of the soul -- 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but, c'mon! You draw 'em like pancakes! I mean, they're WAY out of proportion! He's having fun, but she remains serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes are how I express my emotions. That's how I've always drawn them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was little, I had surgery that left me deaf for a period. I couldn't hear, so I found myself staring... Relying on people's eyes... She smiles shyly. Understanding, he smiles back. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter? Hey -- Walt! Walter spins, startled. A FRIENDLY GUY in a suit strolls

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that was you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Uh... er, hi, Don.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I'm glad to see you! Have we heard back from the city, on that setback? My guys really need the variance, for the first floor retail. Walter is mortified. He turns away from Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... we should hear from Permits by Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well that's terrif'! I'll tell the architects! Pleased, the guy cheerily strides away.

dialogues.speaker: ON WALTER AND MARGARET
dialogues.text: He is stricken. Something ominous just happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?? 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I didn't want you to know... A long, horrible pause. Walter's face turns gray. We SLOW PUSH IN. This revelation is churning. Agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in commercial real estate. A stunned beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a -- Realtor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YES! A hugely successful Realtor! Top earner in the Downtown office three years running!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're... ashamed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! Any blockhead can arrange a sublet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I ever wanted was to support myself as an artist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to make a clean break, but couldn't cut it. I'm just a goddam Sunday painter. An amateur. Margaret looks at him, touched by his vulnerability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End of the day. Golden light slants in through the window this small tidy apartment. The door opens. Margaret holds it for Walter, who chivalrously staggers in, carrying all her supplies: Ease paints, cans. He carefully puts it all down -- then turns Beat. Walter stares at Margaret, their faces caught in th warm light. Then, enchanted, he kisses her. Silence. Margaret smiles, captivated. Caught in his glow. The mome could last forever... 14.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DOORWAY
dialogues.text: Jane stares unhappily. Threatened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A-hem!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns, startled. Feeling guilty, Margaret rushes from Walter. Busying herself, she skims through the MAIL. Jane shakes her head and marches out. Margaret flips through envelopes -- until one stops her. edge, she slowly removes an official DOCUMENT. She scans it... and her face drops. Crushed. Something terrible... Walter is worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank wants to take away Jane. He says I'm an unfit mother... Walter is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a perfect mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told the court Jane doesn't have a proper home. It's beyond my abilities as a single woman... Margaret trails off, shaken. Walter gulps unsurely. Then, he takes her in his arms. We SLOWLY PUSH IN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marry me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter! I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he puts a finger to her lips) Shh. Don't think of a reason to say no. 'Cause I've got a million reasons to say yes. (he gives a winning smile) I know it makes no sense!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But just think of the fun we'll have..! And I'll take care of you girls. Margaret stammers, speechless. She doesn't know what to s Walter pulls out his ace. In a debonair move, he creakily drops to his knee. He exudes a hammy, wonderful romance:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, I'm on my knee! C'mon, whatdya say? Let's get married! We can be in Hawaii by the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Hawaii"? M-marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, I'm crazy about you... but I'm overwhelmed. Why would we go to Hawaii?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're a princess... and you deserve to get married in paradise.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Margaret shudders, tears in her eyes. Hawaiian MUSIC begi

dialogues.speaker: STOCK FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: A propeller-driven PAN AM airplane soars through the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawaii, 1958. Heaven on earth. Blossoming flowers, rare birds, lush greenery. Margaret is experiencing total blis We widen. She and Walter stand in front of a waterfall, getting married. Jane is Maid-of-Honor. A PRIEST smiles, Walter places a ring on Margaret's finger. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret and Walter lie on the sand, making out. Cuddling running their fingers along each other's bodies. She star up, endlessly happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right... this is paradise. Only God could make those colors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd love it. 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, can't we stay here forever??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know about forever. But maybe... I can arrange another week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatched umbrellas, Polynesian fun. Margaret is set-up, drawing PORTRAITS of the GUESTS. Walter regales them as t wait. Joking, gregariously handing out Mai-Tais. Margaret finishes a picture. She beams at Walter... then signs the picture "KEANE." Walter gapes, astonished at this gesture. Margaret lock e with him. She smiles girlishly, radiating happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old school Cantonese: Dragons and red lacquer. Margaret e lunch with Dee-Ann, showing off SNAPSHOTS from the trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a waterfall... the air was so fresh you could taste it. Here's an ancient altar... that statue is Kane, the god of creation. I said a prayer to him. Oh! Here's Walter and Janie, building a sandcastle -- Dee-Ann raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all happening mighty quick. In the time you moved here, I've had two dates. You're already married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought there was a void in my life. Well... Walter's filled it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's filled a lot of things. He's diddled every skirt on the art circuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking about my husband!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! That's why I brought it up. Margaret frowns, insulted. 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not naive. (beat; she laughs) Well, I am naive. But I know the man I'm marrying. Walter can act rash... but he's a good provider. And he's wonderful with Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- we're both looking for a fresh start. I'm a divorcee with a child. Walter is a blessing. Dee-Ann bites her tongue. The WAITER brings over the chec Sitting on it are TWO FORTUNE COOKIES. Hm. Margaret stares, utterly serious. She reaches for one then impulsively grabs the other. She cracks the cookie. Ann waits, curious. Margaret reads... then slowly smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You are on the threshold of untold success."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Modish, happening gallery. The white walls are hung wit ABSTRACT EXPRESSIONISM: Slashing angles of color, painted rags and glued bolts. On the floor is SCULPTURE made from wood and wire. In charge is RUBEN, a fussy man in a goatee. He's schmooz a FANCY LADY. They look at a spattered, distorted paintin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's brilliant about the composition is its spontaneity. The image has no visual center of attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quite gestural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh definitely! Strongly influenced by the tachistes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard Tab Hunter was in here, looking at one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I'm not allowed to say... He NODS HIS HEAD up-and-down: Yes, you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car backfires. Ruben turns -- and winces. 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windows is Walter, climbing out of his massiv white Cadillac. He's all done up, in beret and scarf. He opens the giant trunk and removes a pile of paintings. Ruben cringes knowingly. He whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Christ, don't come in here. Please don't come in here... The door SLAMS. Walter loudly barges in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruben, good day! Do you got a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter. In polite society, the word is "appointment."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing back and forth) Uh, I could come back later... She anxiously hurries for the door. Ruben fumes. Walter ignores it all and starts laying out his wares. Fi the Parisian street scenes, one after another...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna love my stuff today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't I seen that one before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah! That was painted in the Fifth Arrondissement. This is the Sixth Arrondissement!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. You lived in Paris for a week. How can you still be cranking out paintings? Walter laughs. He points to his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all up here. (beat; a sentimental

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here. He points to his heart. Ruben frowns and points to the wa 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's not going up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, you know we don't go for that representational jazz! You're too literal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Art isn't fashion!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it IS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People want Kandinsky, or Rothko! They don't want goopy street scenes.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Ouch! This stings terribly. Walter glares at the man, then softly slides aside his wo Quietly, he pulls out Margaret's Big Eye paintings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would they want... this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God! You've entered a new period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... they're my wife's. Fascinated, Ruben glances through Margaret's oils. Canvas after canvas of sad kiddies against gray, bleak backgroun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are their eyes so big?! They're like big stale jellybeans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Expressionism. Surely you recognize it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I'm just glad you two found each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... what do you say? Ruben looks up, amazed. Walter seems oblivious. 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, NO! It's not art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not -- "art"??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like the back of a magazine! "Draw the turtle! Send in a nickel and win the Big Contest!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you! Lots of people would like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, nobody who's walking through the door of this gallery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now please! Clear out this clutter, before the taste police arrives. Walter's jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The hungry i" -- the hottest nightclub around, so hip it a basement. The marquee says "Cal Tjader, TONIGHT!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A swinging mob of BEAUTIFUL PEOPLE -- suits, gowns and pe CAL TJADER'S BAND is crazed: Vibes and bongo-driven JAZZ. Margaret and Walter are squeezed at a table. She nurses a Grasshopper. Walter's in a foul mood, CHUGGING cocktails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll never break in...! Because there's a CABAL. A secret society of gallery owners and critics, who get together for Sunday brunch in Sausalito, deciding what's "cool."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're like Freemasons. No, worse! McCarthy, in his hearings: "That painter, I anoint. That painter, I banish to nowheresville!" Heartfelt, Margaret disagrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think people buy art because it touches them -- 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heh! You're livin' in fairy land! People don't get to discover a thing. They buy art, because it's in the right place at the right time. O.s., MUSIC BUILDS. Muddled, Walter turns. He looks -- an then -- his eyes light up. He is getting an idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band speeds to a climax, the percussion throbbing. Th a final, crazed note. BAM!! The crowd APPLAUDS. The club's owner, ENRICO BANDUCCI, bo on stage. Banducci is a theatrical, natty Italian guy wit skinny moustache and loud personality. He grabs a mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it up for Cal Tjader! That set was HUMMIN'! Al-aright, be sure to stick around for the one a.m. show! The house lights come up. Banducci hops down, greeting guests, making his way out -- when Walter glides up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Banducci. I love the music tonight. It's a gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Walter Keane. I'm a painter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was looking at your walls, and they're pretty plain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Hm...! Maybe you're right. What color were you thinking? Huh? Walter holds his composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I'm an artist. I used to be based on the Left Bank. But now I've relocated to the "States," and I'm looking for an... exhibition venue. Beat. Banducci frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like my club the way it is. Your stuff's so hot, go put it in a museum. 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay! I respect that. You're a businessman, not a charity! So how 'bout if I, uh... rented your walls? Hm?! Banducci raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's swanky pad is CHAOS, filled with cameras and lig A PHOTOGRAPHER runs around, tweaking equipment. Walter's at an easel, putting the final touches on a PAIN of a French street scene. He gabs on the PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! The paintings are available for public viewing daily, from 7 to 3! (an awkward beat) Er, no. 3 a.m. It's in a nightclub. (he hangs up) Maggie! It's promotion time! We gotta lay the racket! Margaret puts on a smock, a bit dumbfounded. Walter spatt some paint on his shirt. He grins, then holds up his brus and SIGNS the painting: "W. KEANE" Margaret forces a "cheese" smile, with her Waif. FLASH! T camera pops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU - A cheery BROCHURE, "Meet the Keanes!" There's a stag PHOTO: Walter at his street scene, Margaret at her Waif. Then -- a SHOE steps on it. We WIDEN... revealing the brochure on the sticky floor of... THE CLUB! It throbs with frolicking CUSTOMERS. We move through the pack. To a rear concrete hallway... to a sign with an arrow: "TOILETS." We go down the hall... into...

dialogues.speaker: A DINGY CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: The Keane paintings hang here. The only human in sight is Walter, forlorn at a card table. Brochures are stacked, a he wears a sailor coat with a dandyish ascot. The image is grim. Walter listens to the raucous mob. Unt THUMP! -- a sloshed MAN stumbles in. Walter brightens and stands. 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, beautiful! An art lover! Yes sir, how may I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm, uh, just looking for the john. A terrible pause. Walter swallows his outrage... then poi The guy smiles and tosses Walter a BUCK, as a tip. Walter stunned. The guy toddles away. Beat. The Ladies Room opens, and TWO GOSSIPY WOMEN rush o oblivious to Walter. He glowers. ANOTHER MAN bounds in, right up to one of Walter's paintings! He stops at it. Walter gathers a moment of hope. Does he like it? Then the man leans down and opens a CLOSET. He removes a of bar glasses, kicks the door shut, and scoots away.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He grimaces... beaten. Walter drops his head on the table Not noticing a DRUNK COUPLE stagger in. They pass a Waif, then halt -- taken. They lean in. Enthralled... concerned

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that child. She's so sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she poor..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's forgotten! It just makes me want to cry. (she peers at the signature, then turns) Are you "Keane"? Walter lifts his head from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you're a hell of a painter. Walter squints, confused, then beams. Joy! Happiness bursting like a little child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, thank you...! Thank you so much! 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your work is very powerful. There's so much emotion in those eyes. OUCH! Walter's smile collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Uh... no. No. I just didn't realize you meant... the waif.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat; he CHUCKLES) Oh, I get it...! The artist doesn't wanna part with his favorite piece... The man winks, then pulls out a WAD OF BILLS. Walter stares morosely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits at the bar, toasted, drinking. In a dark plac His misery is interrupted by happy Banducci, groping two

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Picasso! Nice crowd, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't know it from that broom closet you parked me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's prime thoroughfare! People drink, they gotta relieve themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Location, location, location..." Walter wallows in self-loathing. Suddenly, he explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's INSULTING! When people see art, they shouldn't think of SHIT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoah! Watch it with the purple language. We got ladies present --! Banducci PUSHES Walter away. 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In reaction, Walter sloppily SMACKS him. Riled, Banducci suddenly takes a SWING! Walter stumbles, Banducci's punch accidently HITS the GIRL. Ow! She topples. Walter gasps. He SWATS Banducci -- then RUNS! Cameras FLASH. Wild whoop Walter barrels down the hall, Banducci chasing. The brawl gone nuts. Walter grabs a Waif and SMASHES it over Banduc head. CRASH! Banducci drops.

dialogues.speaker: SAN FRANCISCO EXAMINER
dialogues.text: The front page! A small headline says "BISTRO BRAWL: BAND AND ARTIST SLUGFEST." Below are two PHOTOS: Walter mid-pu and Banducci unconscious, sticking out of the Big Eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A neighborhood precinct, quiet at 6 a.m. Doors open, and Margaret leads Walter out. She's seething. He's bruised, with a mortified drunk-tank, slept-in-my-clothes swagger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never posted bail before. Silence. He has no idea what to say. His aplomb crumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm -- I'm sorry. Banducci... laughed at our work. ...So I socked him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when are you thin-skinned? Artists have to handle criticism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right! I know. But... I was already in a bad place. I'd had a couple... and earlier...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I let some guy think I painted your Big Eye. Beat. Margaret is stupefied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. Why would you do such a thing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a misunderstanding. And then, I didn't want to jinx the sale. 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs feebly. She frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ever do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The club is a ZOO. PARTYERS swarm the door, trying to ent Suddenly, Walter pushes his way down the outside stairs. DOORMAN starts to protest, but Walter somberly waves him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me a hard time. I'm just grabbing my stuff... Across the packed room, he spots Banducci with a black ey Walter halts, uncertain. A bristling tension... Until -- Banducci suddenly rushes and GRABS him! Walter flails, freaked. Banducci DRAGS him into a back kitchen -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banducci shuts the door, looks around... then suddenly LA He grins manically and pulls Walter into a hearty HUG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe this? We're sold out, and I don't even have a headliner!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, it's a Monday! Walter blinks, lost. Banducci explains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dope, we made the front page!! People are here, cause they wanna see the sappy paintings that made grown men fight!! A moment of discombobulation... until -- Walter slowly gr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men suddenly tumble into view, SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you in COURT, you son of a bitch! I'm suing you for assault! Slander! False arrest!! Banducci storms away. Walter shudders, "upset." CUSTOMERS peer at him... then a the paintings. Curious, they migrate that way... 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter glances sideways. Gauging their reactions... Until -- a swinging middle-aged guy in horn rims and a su lopes up. DICK NOLAN: A man who hides his bored emptiness under a veneer of booze and broads. Dick leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir! Whew. That was quite a load of horseshit you gents were layin' out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick Nolan. The Examiner. Walter freezes up. Until -- Dick grins conspiratorially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey pal, don't lose any sleep. I eat this stuff with a spoon! It gives me something to type about, in my column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he laughs, relieved) I thought you only did celebrities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Banducci's famous -- and you hit him! So you're a celebrity, once- removed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy me a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Uh, sure -- Dick smoothly drags him to the bar. Dick waves the barten

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary! I'll have a Ward Eight, in a frosted high boy. My friend'll have the same. (he beams, then turns) So! Walter, tell me about your work --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when I was in Paris...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, not those! I mean the little hobo kids. What?! Walter frowns, peeved. He considers this indignity then decides to stomach it. He smiles fakely, effusively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you wanna know...?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret is asleep. Suddenly Walter bursts in, drunk and jocular. He FLIPS on the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ding-a-ling! Wake up, we're a HIT! Margaret rolls over, groggy. Walter jumps on the bed, grinning. He tosses her a HANDFUL OF MONEY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a night! I sold out all your Big Eyes!! She rubs her eyes, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be two-hundred dollars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They adore you! Cause of that article, the joint was PACKED. And then, a famous journalist showed up, and -- I need more paintings! Now! He hungrily KISSES her. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, they take at least a week. There's layering, shading --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! But, this is opportunity! Ah, we're gonna make a crackerjack team: Me schmoozing up the club, while you're back here, doing what you love! She stares at him -- then smiles. MUSIC...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret happily paints away. At peace, lost in her art..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sells Big Eyes. Shoving cash into a cigar box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret works, HUMMING serenely. On the easel is a half- finished blonde girl in a blue dress. 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter buys a new suit. A TAILOR measures him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret finishes painting a sad boy, using a fine brush add a watery rim to his eyes. Magically, this detail brin the picture to life. She's pleased. Margaret signs "KEANE." There are two finished canvases, sad little girl and boy. Margaret smiles, her heart swell She loves them. Then, she looks about. Nobody is there to share the moment. Hm. She thinks -- then picks up the PHONE. She dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cava, I'm sorry to bother you so late... but would you mind watching Jane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret rides in the back seat, smiling, her gaze farawa She proudly hugs the bundled paintings to her chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The club is pounding. Margaret enters the throng, carryin her work. She looks up -- and has her breath taken away.

dialogues.speaker: ENTIRE CLUB, EVERY WALL, IS NOW HUNG WITH KEANE PAINTINGS
dialogues.text: Whoa...! Pure joy envelops her. Then -- she gets jostled. Margaret notices Walter holding court with some GROUPIES. She approaches, unnoticed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...yeah, eyes are powerful. A poet said they're the windows of the soul. Margaret smiles, touched. She comes closer....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hold so much feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it! That's why I paint 'em so big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always done it that way.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: She GASPS, stunned. The room starts spinning. 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you like this style, I'm working on a few new pieces. I've got a little blonde girl in a blue dress that'll tear your heart out.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Her face goes ashen. Dizzy, she clutches for support. What to do?? Overcome, she shrinks away... disappearing.. ending up alone in a corner. She cowers, childlike.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Walter LAUGHS at a joke, then backslaps the group. He jovially strides away... passing by Margaret... when --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter...? He spins -- shocked at her presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, uh, what are you doing here? I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you lying? For once, Walter has no answer. She bores in, emotions racing. Confused. Hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're taking credit for something that isn't yours. He looks ill. Wheels spinning, looking for an out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was... trying to close the deal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those children are part of my being!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just a salesman! You know, buyers pay more if they meet the painter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They couldn't meet me, because you told me to stay home!! 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh, QUIET! He grabs her, pulling her behind a curtain. He's desperat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't blow this! Look, we're makin' money! Your pocket, my pocket? What's the difference?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take this so lightly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not all all! But it's not about ego! You wanna say you did the street scenes? Fine! I don't care! Say a monkey painted it! She breaks into tears, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you can dash off your pieces without any emotional connection...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, honey! I just wanna share them with the world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you rather have your children piled in a closet... or hanging in someone's living room? Silence. Then -- FLASH! FLASH! FLASH! Walter turns. And -- his eyes pop, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Is an incredible sight. Like a moment from "La Dolce Vita fabulously dressed ITALIAN MAN with THREE BLONDES floats the stairs, into the club. Cameras FLASH. Walter gapes, transfixed. He grabs Banducci.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Who is that remarkably handsome and confident man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Dino Olivetti -- as in Olivetti typewriters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even try, Walter. He doesn't speak a lick of English. Walter stares hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVETTI
dialogues.text: glides into the club -- a vision of perfection with his s hair and sunglasses. He approaches closer, closer... when gets distracted. By one of Margaret's Big Eye PAINTINGS. Walter gasps. He nudges Margaret. Olivetti peers at the artwork. Intrigued. Then -- excited He starts gesturing and yapping in ITALIAN. The Blondes s back. Everyone is getting worked-up. The big-bosomed Blonde turns to Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Olivetti is enchanted with the painting. He would like to know... who is the artist?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET AND WALTER
dialogues.text: The moment of truth. Margaret opens her mouth... and no s comes out. She clenches up. Stomach tight. Mute. Walter gives her a second -- tick tock tick tock. Then -- leaps into Opportunity. He SMACKS his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am! Walter swoops over and grabs Olivetti in a hearty clasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a delight to meet you, Signore! Buon giorno! Have you been an art lover for long..? We move in tight on MARGARET, as the SOUND DIALS DOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call that piece "The Waif." Isn't it striking? With its juxtaposition of girl, cat, and stairs... and its almost Flemish use of underpigment... The SOUND dims... then goes SILENT. Margaret stares in shock, unmoving. Time seems to stop. She is frozen in grief. Until -- 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby! Baby! Can you believe it?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time has passed. Walter happily clutches Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made five grand!! Five THOUSAND dollars...!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that wasn't even one of your good ones! Margaret blinks, lost. In the b.g., Olivetti holds the painting, now wrapped-up newspaper and twine. A pleased customer. Margaret's face darkens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you mean... one of your good ones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No no! One of -- OUR good ones. (the spirit of generosity, he hands her a CHECK) Look at those zeroes! We've hit the big time! We are now hanging in the collection of Italian industrialist Dino Olivetti! With his patronage comes credibility! And with credibility comes RESPECT! Margaret stares at the check in her hands. At all the zer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about... honesty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw c'mon! The paintings say "Keane"! I'm Keane, you're Keane. From now on, we are one and the same. Walter pulls her tight. She doesn't resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upbeat MUSIC. Walter frantically tosses all the BROCHURES him and Margaret into a FIREPLACE. They burn to ash.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: We ZOOM into Dick Nolan's SOCIETY COLUMN. Under a caricat of Dick is a highlighted ITEM. We hear TYPING:

dialogues.speaker: DICK'S HUSHED VOICE
dialogues.text: "What exactly is local painter Walter Keane up to? My spies tell me a big announcement is forthcoming...!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter proudly hands a painting to the confused-looking M

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On behalf of the children of the world, we present this painting to Mayor Christopher!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter thrusts a painted Ballerina at a SOVIET DIPLOMAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the interest of peace through culture, we donate this painting to the people of Russia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick whispers into a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Purple Onion. 9:30. Joan Crawford has a dinner reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOAN CRAWFORD is eating with friends. Suddenly Walter lun into view, startling her. He lugs a painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Crawford! In recognition of your cinematic craft, we bestow this painting, "The Lion and the Child"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret paints. Walter beams. 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan said "Marvelous"! MARVELOUS! That's worth more than 1000 critics! (he CLAPS his hands) Hey, maybe she'll come to our opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... isn't it strange? Artists get shown. They don't build their own galleries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says who?! Like John Q. Public cares? He's FED UP with abstract neoformalism! She responds -- but he sexily puts his finger to her mout

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He digs real art. Your art! It's beautiful. You're beautiful... Walter starts rubbing against her, dancing sensually. She laughs, embarrassed, her wet paint brushes smearing his c She relents and relaxes. They dance around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the shadows, POSTERS of "The Waif" get glued up. Under woeful face, it says "KEANE GALLERY 494 Broadway." We WID as Walter, Margaret and Jane hastily slap up the posters. They carry glue buckets and a ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruben's gonna choke when he sees this! Little Jane tiredly glues another poster. She yawns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember when Momma painted that. Huh? Suddenly, Margaret freezes. She hadn't anticipated this. Margaret looks to Walter. He stares back, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you -- sure? That was a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I'm sure! It was in our old apartment, and you had me sit on a stool in the kitchen -- 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, dear, I'm afraid you're confused. I painted that one --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mother did! Look! I'm wearing my blue dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L-lots of girls have that dress... Margaret trails off, sickened. Not knowing how to lie. Walter takes charge. He kneels, then smiles gently at Jan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a good eye, sweetie. I painted it, but I was trying to mimic your mother's style. You know, the style she USED to paint in.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: A loooooong pause. She examines the print. Then... she no

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you did a really good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU on the Waif. We widen, revealing the ENTIRE WORLD has hijacked, blanketed by THE POSTERS. People gape -- astoni and captivated. Disconnected from it all, strolling alone, is Margaret. S is burdened by her own thoughts. Regretful... Across the street, she sees a GOTHIC CHURCH. She stares u awed by the beauty. It's Catholic imagery in all its glor Saints... Jesus... Mary... Suddenly -- the bells RING. Hm. Margaret takes a step...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret tentatively enters and kneels. Beat -- then the grille OPENS. She reacts, discomposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. I've -- never really done this before. I'm not sure how you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was raised Methodist. If it's a problem, I can go -- 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to stand. The Priest blurts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no! Please. We don't chase people away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is troubling you? Margaret takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lied to my child. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband... he pressured me into doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never lied to her before. I'm not that kind of person. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your husband that kind of person?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummm, no. I don't think of him that way. I mean, he likes to tell stories... maybe he exaggerates a little... but he's a good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes care of us. He wants to make enough money to buy our family a house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what of the child? Will this lie bring harm to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Harm"?? Oh! Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just looking for answers... The Priest considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the modern world is a complicated place.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST'S VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Occasionally, children need to be sheltered from certain truths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: N-no. That's not what --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds like your husband is trying to make the best of an imperfect situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were raised Christian, so you know what we are taught: The man is head of the household.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you should trust his judgment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening night! The gallery is packed with the IN CROWD: R and drinking. The space is cool -- the walls bright white the art hanging under spotlights. JAZZ plays on the stere At one painting, a HIPSTER COUPLE stares at the image of sorrowful girl holding an armful of poodle puppies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's creepy, maudlin and amateurish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. I love it. We move in tight on the painting. Underneath is a tag: "BEDTIME, by WALTER KEANE. Oil on canvas." We drift along, to another painting: "CALICO CAT, by WALT KEANE." Then, another: "IN THE GARDEN, by WALTER KEANE." Every painting is now by Walter Keane. We move along... finding the Tipsy Man chatting up Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got in early. We own three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, doll. He tosses his empty to a PASSING LADY. We reveal the wait is... Margaret. She carries a tray of pigs-in-a-blanket. Margaret looks shell-shocked -- faking a happy party face A burst of LAUGHTER. Margaret turns. 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and a group ROAR at a joke. A SEXY GIRL hands Walt one of the promo posters. He beams and lays it across her back... hugging her waist to "steady" himself as he signs

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON MARGARET
dialogues.text: She frowns. Dee-Ann slides into view, slurping champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, baby! Killer party! It's a hap- pen-ing...! So, where's your stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Um, we decided that this would be Walter's show --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh "we" did?? And why would "we" do that??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... he's more established.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! Is that you talking, or did you just turn into a little felt puppet with someone's hand up your ass? Margaret is befuddled. Dee-Ann scopes out the artwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's strange... Walter doesn't strike me as the cute hungry kitten type... Margaret grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming. Margaret grabs a drink and hurries away. Dee-Ann stands there, irked. Margaret cuts over to Walter. We MOVE IN TIGHT ON THE COU He grins and grabs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, my sweet! Are you enjoying the scene? (he gives her a kiss)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give a hand to my beautiful wife. Without her, none of tonight would be possible! The crowd APPLAUDS politely, condescendingly. Margaret smiles strangely. The Tipsy Man leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband's quite a talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you paint, too? Margaret freezes up, terribly awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't... know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NOSY GUY corners him in front of a painted child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm curious about your technique. How long did that piece take to execute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That? Oh, wow. Probably... months. First the thinking, the sketching, and then time with just me and the oils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oils"? But isn't that acrylic...? Huh? Walter glances at the painting, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh --! You mean that painting! Uhh, sorry! It's like a jumble of ideas, rattling around in my brain! Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where do you get your ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean -- (confused at this confusion) Why are they... images of children? Yikes. Walter starts to sweat. He didn't think this throu 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, er, I've just always loved kids. Though mostly I was influenced by my darling daughter... An odd beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember when she was a baby... Walter gets a far-off look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cute little thing. I'd stare into those big orbs. Sometimes I'd get out my Brownie and snap a photo... but... that's not subjective. You know? It doesn't capture your feelings. So that's when I started painting her... We hold on Walter, unsure where reality begins and ends..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU on a fuzzy TV SCREEN: A PRIGGISH MAN is griping. The screen is captioned "JOHN CANADAY, NY TIMES ART CRITIC"

dialogues.speaker: CANADAY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Keane's work is completely without distinction. He is not a member of the Society of Western Artists. He has won no awards. He's only noteworthy for his appearances in a certain newspaper's gossip column!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keane is why society NEEDS critics! To protect them from such atrocities! Walter gapes at the TV, outraged. He suddenly grabs a PHO

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Jane is BANGING on a closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom! I wanna come in.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Uhh, you can't. Mommy's busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she BANGS again) Let me in! What are you doing in there? Why's the door always locked? 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter enters -- and reacts. He glides over to the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie, sweetie, you need to respect your mother's privacy. Sometimes grownups need alone time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the ice cream truck? Why don't you go get yourself a fudgesicle? Walter tosses her a dime. She peers warily, then leaves. He waits a beat -- then pulls out a KEY. Walter discreetl unlocks the painting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a factory. Big Eyes are everywhere. Margaret frenzie works, surrounded by half-done canvases, solvents, easels She's in a bathrobe -- a cigarette hanging from her lips. Startled, she looks up to see Walter. He gazes at all the art. At the bulbous faces, eyes water and submissive, trapped in muddy yellows and dire browns. then... Walter grins broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew! Out of this world...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. I'm not really comfortable with this. Jane and I used to be so close... but -- now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Jane's grand! She's eating ice cream! She has new shoes. She has a college fund. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm lightheaded from the turpentine. I've been in here all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't want you feeling like a prisoner. Take a break! Walter glances at one PAINTING -- then does a take.

dialogues.speaker: PAINTING
dialogues.text: It's a child in a rusty alley, staring, aching for compas And, starting to cry. A single tear streams down her chee 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a tear...? You've gone deep! Margaret bites her fingers, worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you -- like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it! ...How'd you get the eyes so lifelike? Is it the highlights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The secret is the shadow. I shadowed the eyelid. Margaret smiles shyly. Walter smiles back, full of warmth He takes her face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owe you an apology. I was initially dismissive of your kids, those emotion- wrenching blobs of humanity... but they have a real strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your best version of sincerity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying! Ah, you know me. See -- this is why I need your help! I want to go on tv, to defend our art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to be on television?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! But... what will I say??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning -- what compels me... to paint... these paintings?? A bizarre pause. The two of them look around the room. At all the Big Eyes peering down at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you have an unhealthy obsession with little girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cute. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you've painted yourself into a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny! Keep 'em coming! You're a regular Steve Allen. You want heat this winter? Help me out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter... art is personal. Walter picks up a picture of TWO LITTLE GIRLS IN TUTUS. H stares, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would make a grown man paint a picture like this?! No answer. He thinks of stories, wheels spinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grew up, surrounded by six sisters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grew up in an orphanage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grew up... in a world where adults had vanished, and children and kittens ran wild over the desolate landscape! Margaret smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your Paris street scenes? Why do you paint those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, because... I lived it! I experienced it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling his bluff) And was it really all sun-dappled streets and flower vendors? Huh? Walter stares off at the Waifs. They peer out from broken windows... chain-link fences... And then -- he gets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- NO! Of course not. It was after the War. There was destruction everywhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I traveled the Continent. The ravages were horrifying...

dialogues.speaker: FULL FRAME TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: Walter is on TV, on a LOCAL PUBLIC AFFAIRS SHOW. He's coa with makeup, sitting rigidly, fingers gripping his chair.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: My psyche was scarred in my art student days. Nothing in my life has ever made such an impact as the sight of the children: War-wracked innocents, without homes, without parents, fighting over garbage... He sits in a half-circle of PROPER WOMEN, who are spellbo

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Goaded by a frantic despair, I sketched these dirty, ragged little victims... with their bruised minds and bodies, their matted hair and runny noses. There my life as a painter began in earnest. Walter sadly looks up to the HOST. The man is shellshocked. Mute. Walter waits, then sighs.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: The insane, inhuman cruelty inflicted upon these children cut deeply into my being. From that moment on, I painted the lost children with the eyes. Those eyes that forever retained their haunting quality. The ladies are stricken. A few dab their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keane posters get RIPPED off a wall. RIPPED off a mailbox. PULLED off a construction site!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter strides along, a bounce to his step. He reaches th gallery -- then stops, dumbfounded. It's PACKED with PEOP Not rich, but regular folks, gawking at the art. 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. A sweet moment... then some TOURISTS see Walter and happily accost him: "Walter Keane!" "Mr. Keane!" They thr papers and POSTERS at him to autograph. Walter grins and scribbles his signature. Glancing over t shoulders, he sees Ruben down the block, standing outside own gallery. Gaping in disbelief. Walter chuckles... then flips him off. Ruben's face falls

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter pushes through, shaking hands, greeting the CUSTOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon! Delighted! (he reaches the SEXY BLONDE CLERK and pinches her ass) How many sales today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sales?" None with this crowd. Walter's smile drops, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people are looky-loos! They can't afford the paintings. But we gave away a heap of posters! Huh? Walter peers, baffled. Suddenly -- a loud FRWWIPPPP! Walter whirls, startled. Outside, two GIRLS tear a big po off the front window. Walter's eyes widen. Slowly, he turns back. At the counte FOLKS and KIDS are grabbing free posters from a box. Walter stares. Processing this. And then... being struck an idea of absolute genius...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is on the telephone, peering through the doorway. Hiding from the customers. Spying. WHISPERING.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: It's the craziest thing. I started charging for the posters! First a nickel... then a dime. (struggling to whisper) YES, Maggie! It's cuckoo! So it got me thinkin': Would you rather sell a $500 painting, or a million cheaply- reproduced posters?! (he LAUGHS, exultant)

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: See, folks don't care if it's a copy. They just want art that touches them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then... we could sell it anywhere!! EVERYWHERE! 60's-style MADISON AVENUE GRAPHICS: A still of a HARDWARE STORE. Mops, light bulbs, then -- BING! -- framed KEANES. A PHARMACY. Aspirin, candy bars -- BING! -- framed KEANES A GAS STATION. Tires, motor oil, and -- BING! -- KEANES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aisle of Sundries: Plastic toys, beach balls... Waifs. sign says "WE HAVE KEANE!" Around the corner, Margaret shuffles along, listlessly bu banalities: Cereal. Soap. She turns the cart... and runs into her wall of teary-eyed kids. Margaret peers, muddled. Then she turns away -- to a RACK OF PAPERBACKS. They offe fast hope, inspiration. Margaret seems disconnected. She runs her hand down the options... a book of Numerology... book on Judaism... an Edgar Cayce prophecies manual... AT THE REGISTER - Margaret gazes up. The CASHIER is a sad Beatnik Girl. In a haze, Margaret notices the whole marke full of LONELY WOMEN: One LADY is her doppelganger -- same age, blonde, grippin cart. Next aisle over, a MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN stares into sp Nearby, a YOUNG MOM wrangles her children. We shift to Margaret. Face gaunt. Eyes empty. Troubled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtains drawn, Margaret frantically SKETCHES. She's cabi feverish. In her robe. Hair dirty. And -- up to something These sketches aren't squat children with round eyes. The different: Figures with long lines. Margaret frowns and rips the paper. She tries again! Anot angular figure -- straight fingers... no! Again! A woman... reclining. Then an indication of a face A slash... and then -- two small almond shapes for eyes. 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. Margaret's face brightens. She likes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret rabidly paints. Spurting globs of color. The wom is blonde, almond eyes cool, lips curled with mystery... Margaret glances in a mirror. It's a self-portrait. It's Margaret, aloof. Alone at a table. Suddenly the door opens. Margaret GASPS, startled, and sp the canvas away. Walter barges in, dressed like a million He HALTS -- making a sour face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew! Something smells in here. You should open a window. Margaret blinks, a bit dazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. 6:30, 7? ...Didn't Janie get dinner? Margaret shrugs. Walter leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the last time you washed your hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been... busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he notices the turned canvas; he's intrigued) What do you got back there? Lemme see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No --! It's just... something I'm working on. It's not for the world. Walter gives her a funny look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The world"? Baby, it's me! (stepping forward, a bit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your number one fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please! Walter, it's -- personal. 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we're husband and wife. We shouldn't have secrets... Margaret gulps, fretting. Finally, without options -- she flips over the canvas of the lonely blonde. And -- Walter is taken aback. His eyebrows raise, shocked Margaret bites her lip. Will he go ballistic?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He leans right up to the painting. His expression is inscrutable. Studying the technique. We have no idea what his emotion is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a completely different style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a self-portrait. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I gonna explain that? She shifts about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought... maybe... I could sign it myself. Hmm. Walter's eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That seems a bit confusing. "Keane" means me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know... but... when people ask me if I paint, I don't know what to answer! I just want the pride of being able to say -- that's mine. Walter's wheels are ratcheting. 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd you tell about the Big Eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was Dee-Ann here?! Did Dee-Ann see this painting?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! NOBODY saw it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell anybody, the empire COLLAPSES! Do you wanna give back the money? We've committed FRAUD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I KNOW! My God! I live with this every minute of my life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie used to have a mother who painted. Now what's she think?! I lock myself in this room ten hours a day... and then you walk out with finished paintings! He scowls, offended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie thinks I'm in here, painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon! You haven't picked up a brush in months! (starting to sob) We used to paint together! Easels next to each other, side-by-side --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the honeymoon period! Margaret breaks into tears. Walter tenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you're so fragile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've kept my end of the bargain! I've never told! (she SOBS harder) Please! Just let me have this! Walter recoils, unable to take this. He relents. 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another PHOTO OP, but big: A CAMERA CREW rushes about. Li get set-up. Walter, Margaret, and Jane work at easels. Walter dabs at a Big Eye. Margaret works on a sad, long-n blonde. Jane paints a goofy flower, like any child. Dick Nolan takes notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're now called "The Painting Keanes"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep! Walter and his girls! With galleries in three cities!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea Margaret painted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we don't talk about it. Sadly, people don't buy lady art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Georgia O'Keefe? Dick shakes his EMPTY GLASS, distracted. Walter points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar's over there. Dick goes to get a refill. Walter shoots Margaret a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Margaret's a superb artist, in her own way. I even steal a few tips from her, now and then!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind every great man is a great woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True true. So Margaret, where do you get your ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit tentative) Oh... from the world around me. And I love Modigliani's use of line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ModiWHAT? The Italian joint? 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for Christ's sake, Margaret! Dick writes a gossip column --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's stick to the family angle. Get a gander at little Janie over there! Walter steers Dick to Jane, cute at her little child's ea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a talent! Look at these Keanes! If you cut open our veins, we bleed oil! Er -- turpentine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Dick, you know what I'm goin' for. Make it sound good. DING-DONG! It's the doorbell. Everyone turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! A little treat! The fourth member of the Painting Keanes! Margaret and Jane turn, confused. Walter whips open

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Revealing LILY, 10, a quiet girl in bobbed hair. She hold little overnight bag. A Buick HONKS, and Walter waves as it drives away. Walter stares at the girl, then puts on big hammy airs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily, honey, how are you?! He gives her a giant hug. She responds stiffly -- a girl doesn't see her father too often.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, Dad. I lost a tooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Did you get in a fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It fell out!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET AND JANE
dialogues.text: They gape in bewilderment. Who the hell is this girl 53.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON WALTER AND LILY
dialogues.text: Walter admires Lily's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well is the tooth fairy somethin' I gotta deal with, or did your mother already handle it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She handled it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! Good good! Well, just go throw your stuff in the kids' room, then you can come join the fun! Lily toddles out.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE GROUP
dialogues.text: Margaret and Jane are speechless. Walter acts like nothing bizarre has happened. Dick eyeballs all this with major curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter... you never told me you had another daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I? Sure. Lil's from my first marriage. Margaret struggles to hold her rage. Disoriented...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter! We need to speak. Margaret gestures: Get in the kitchen! He nods and follow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret shuts the door, then spins on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is going on here

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Lily. I'm sure I mentioned her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you didn't. 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret peers at him. How much can she trust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she just move in??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Her mom's just going to Vegas for the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to have her once a month, but I don't make her mom enforce it.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: Her head is spinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
