dialogues.text: How can you keep something so big a secret???

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: He starts to answer... then gives her a look: You are kid Walter squirms defensively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a sweet girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put up with your daughter. I never said a peep. Margaret's jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna pretend you didn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Sorry! Please... let's just try to get through this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's room, cute with stuffed animals and troll dolls. Lily is in the corner, awkwardly unpacking her bag. Tryin not to impose on Jane's space. The girls peer at each oth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad told me you had a bunk bed. 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane shakes her head. She feels bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the bed. I can sleep on the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's not fair! The floor's fine for me. Jane smiles nervously. She stares at this new girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you live far away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess... about a twenty minute drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Twenty minutes"?! That's close! Jane blinks, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you never see Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I see him all the time! He comes up and visits every week. Jane is taken aback. Lily sees this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't he talk about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Uh... sure. I guess a little. Jane thinks, fretting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he talk about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... yeah. Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's your mom like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's pretty. She drives a Buick. She cries a lot. 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, mine's the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except she drives a Packard. Lily nods. Jane lowers her voice naughtily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some peanut butter hidden in my sock drawer. Do you wanna eat it? Lily smiles: Sure. Jane opens a drawer and removes a jar Skippy. The two girls sit on the floor, happily eating th peanut butter with their fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klieg lights streak the sky! A crazed CROWD is packed INS A big sign announces: "NOW APPEARING: AMERICA'S FIRST FAM OF ART - 'We paint truth and emotion.'"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is filled with Big Eyes. Waifs waifs waifs! Cas registers RING. Money changes hands. "Sold" stickers go u Walter works the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Walter Keane and Gauguin have a lot in common. They both walked away from successful careers to travel the globe, live on a boat... We move... finding Margaret alone in a small ANNEX. It displays a few of her sad blondes, alongside Jane and Lil paintings of flowers and Mr. Potato-Head. Margaret sits, seeming like an adult at the children's table. An urbane RICH MAN glides by... and is taken with one of Margaret's nubile blondes. He gazes at the lounging figur Margaret sits up. Alert, pleased with his interest. She tingles. Then, happily excited, unable to hold it in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I painted it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very evocative. ...Sensual... He smiles flirtatiously. She smiles shyly and shrugs. 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps forward -- then peers closer at the painting. Th SIGNATURE is a feminine scroll: "MDH Keane"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "MDH"? You're so... mysterioso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we don't use my name, since people don't take women's art seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "MDH" are my initials. And more! I'm interested in numerology... and as you know, seven is a very good number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er... seven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luckily, my maiden name is Margaret Doris Hawkins! "M" is the 13th letter of the alphabet, "D" is 4, "H" 8! If you add up 1 and 3 in 13, that gives you 4, making 4 plus 4 plus 8 equals 16, then 1 plus 6 equals seven! The man's head is spinning. He's lost all interest. Across the room, Walter sees this debacle. He marches ove

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psst! Maggie! Can I have a second? (he PULLS HER ASIDE) Good grief! What the hell are you babbling about?! Long division?? Could you please help the world and shut your mouth? You want just one number in his head: The sales price! Her face drops, hurt. Acquiescing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two SNOBBY ARTISTS smirk and GROAN at this scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two nuts that fell from the same tree! It's insufferable. Why are we starving, while they print money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because that nut's a genius! He sells paintings! Then he sells pictures of the paintings! Then he sells postcards of pictures of the paintings. 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare bitterly. Then, a terrible, shameful idea form

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet I could bang one out in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't have the dopey sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The customers won't notice... They peer sheepishly at each other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruben is walking past -- then stops, pained. A window dis of Keane Big Eyes shares space with paintings of CUTESY KITTENS lapping up milk. We WIDEN, revealing a whole wall of rip-offs! All with od anonymous signatures: "Gig." "Eve." "Igor." A cavalcade o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS HOBOS... PLAYING IN PAJAMAS. But these children aren't sad. They're just... blank. Ruben gasps at the dead-eyed pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ. It's a movement.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION
dialogues.text: "The Tonight Show" opening CREDITS:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's "The Tonight Show!" With guests Jerry Lewis, the Everly Brothers, artists Walter and Margaret Keane -- The CHANNEL CHANGES: A children's toy commercial (STOCK). tear-streaked, crying plastic DOLL, a flagrant Waif rip-o

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She's "Little Miss No Name," the doll with the tear. From Hasbro. The CHANNEL CHANGES: Spanish TELEVISION. A Keane painting gets hung in Madrid's National Museum of Contemporary Art

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Margaret sweatshop is going full-blast. Canvases are everywhere: Melancholy MDH ladies. Woeful Keane kids. Eve portrait of Natalie Wood, copied from a photo. Margaret d a tiny brush, quickly detailing the tear on a child's che when the doorbell CHIMES. Hm? Margaret puts down her brush, wipes her hands, then hurries out. She opens the door... REVEALING THAT WE'RE I DIFFERENT HOUSE. A GIANT, PHENOMENAL 1960s EXTRAVAGANZA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret runs across the marble floors, past the swooping Modern lines of a California ranch... all-white furniture kidney-shaped pool glistening blue outside the glass... a TOY POODLE barking at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rembrandt, shush! In the foyer, Margaret opens the front door. And standing there is Dee-Ann. Dazzled. She laughs with surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God! I thought I misread the address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That driveway is long. (she giggles, embarrassed) Honestly, I can't believe I live here. Dee-Ann glides in -- then freezes, agape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! Two acres, a pool, five

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though I thought that was excessive, since there's only three of us here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three? I thought there were four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- you mean Lily! No, she doesn't really live with us. That was just in the articles. 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy. A fake daughter... Dee-Ann's eyes take it all in. Astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been so long since I've seen you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. North Beach is 30 miles, but it might as well be 300...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're probably busy, hanging out with your new rich buddies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Kim Novak."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please! She's Walter's friend. (a quiet shrug) He brings people by... the Beach Boys were here. But, it's pretty isolated. Dee-Ann goes silent. Margaret seems dwarfed by the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane has nice friends. Sometimes I pick them up at the junior high, and we all get pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's busy... Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! I'll whip us up two gin fizzes. Margaret forces a smile and scurries behind a giant curve bar. She pulls out ingredients: Gin, lemon juice, soda...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we moved in, I thought a wet bar was extravagant... but it's surprising how much use you can get out of it. Dee-Ann watches the drinkmaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He couldn't be happier. He has everything he ever dreamed of. 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so do you! Fabulous. Dee-Ann smiles archly. She glances away -- and notices Margaret's STUDIO, the door half-open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is that your studio? Margaret turns -- and gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No --! You can't go in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want a peek. See what the workspace of a wildly successful artist looks like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dee-Ann, please! STOP -- Margaret rushes to block her -- but Dee-Ann pushes open t door, revealing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room full of MDHs and Keanes. Dee-Ann stops, puzzled. She glances at Margaret -- who ha turned white as a ghost. Immensely curious, Dee-Ann slowly enters. She peers aroun the two styles of paintings... A strained silence. Finally, Margaret whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-Walter paints in here too. Hmm. Dee-Ann walks about, examining the canvases. Then, her ga settles on the Big Eye that Margaret was working on. Below the easel is the wet brush on the open jar of paint Margaret sucks in her breath. Dee-Ann sees this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Walter home?? Margaret has no answer. The two friends look at each other... Dee-Ann waiting... wondering if Margaret is going to lie to her... 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When..... SLAM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both women startle. FOOTSTEPS. Then... Walter strides in! Margaret's eyes pop. Walter's pop even bigger. He glares at the ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on here?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... Dee-Ann was just... she... Margaret trails off. Walter thinks, then SNAPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You KNOW I don't like anyone seeing my work before it's done! Walter rushes to the Waif, then for show grabs up the wet brush and quickly starts to "finish" the painting. Suddenly -- an odd expression crosses his face. He eyebal the canvas, realizing he doesn't know what to do. A furtive glance. Then, unbowed, he hastily dips the brus and slaps a little black onto the shaded background. Walter spins, victorious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three sit silently, tension thick, sipping gin fizzes Nobody speaks. Walter finishes his drink and pours a fresh one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are drunk and SCREAMING. Walter pushes Dee-Ann out t door. 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your whole non-representational crowd are FRAUDS!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHUT UP! You're so full of shit, Walter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get outta my house! My big house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to sellin' your coat hanger sculptures on Fisherman's Wharf!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you! Dee-Ann staggers outside, then hops in her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dee-Ann GUNS the engine and squeals away. The car peels d the very long driveway. Margaret and Walter watch the car disappear into the dist Without looking over, Walter speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want her ever invited here again. Margaret nods, terribly sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret and Walter lie in bed, awake. Arms crossed. Unspeaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret and 13-YEAR-OLD JANE play on the lawn with the poodle. Jane laughs as the dog chases in circles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, Rembrandt! Get the ball! She tumbles, and Rembrandt licks her ear. She giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, honey. I have to go work. 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come? (an awkward silence) No. I can never come. No! I shouldn't even ask. Jane glares glumly. Margaret peers hopelessly at her daughter... then goes in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret strolls to her studio. WE SEE the poodle scamper behind her on its cute little legs. She enters the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret doesn't notice the tiny dog follow her in. She L the door, then turns -- surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you appear from? Didn't you hear? No visitors! Rembrandt wags his tail, his little eyes bright. Margaret peers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this what it's come to? You're the only living soul I can tell my secret? (she lowers her voice) Well -- I painted them all! (she shudders with release) It's TRUE! I did every single one -- She gestures, then catches sight of a Walter street scene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, every one except that street scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I did the rest. Every Big Eye! And nobody will ever know. But YOU. Rembrandt pants and BARKS. Margaret chuckles, then goes to work. She pulls a CURTAIN across the sliding glass door. At her easel, she squirts tube into a well and starts mixing colors. Rembrandt jumps on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't! It's nice to have company, but that sofa is new. (she pushes him off) Let's find you some carpet to lay on. 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret goes over to a CLOSET. Rembrandt follows, curiou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret turns on the bare bulb inside. It's filled with easels... cans... junk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think there's a scrap back here... She rummages, sliding the junk aside. In back is a TATTER WOODEN CRATE. Hm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what's this? Margaret swings the bulb closer. The crate is covered wit SHIPPING INSTRUCTIONS and international markings. Margaret's interest is piqued. She tugs at the lid, pulli it off. Revealing inside a STACK OF STREET SCENE PAINTING Ten or fifteen of Walter's canvases. Or so it seems.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: She peers closer.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: The top painting is a typical Parisian street scene: Cobb stones, a man carrying baguettes, an old lady selling ros But down in the bottom corner is the signature: "S. CENIC

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: She sucks in her breath, shocked. She examines the painti Then, she hurriedly grabs the next canvas. It's another sunlit scene: A quaint Parisian cafe, a man playing accor and in the bottom right corner... the signature: "S. CENI WHAT?! Margaret grabs the next canvas. "S. CENIC" The next canvas. The next canvas! They all are signed "S. CENIC" Margaret starts hyperventilating. 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks, then suddenly bolts from the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret races, rushing up to Walter's painted street sce hung on the wall. We PUSH IN TIGHT, as she shoves her fac to the canvas, so close we can see the brushstrokes -- As we MOVE IN TO THE SIGNATURE. Simply, "W. KEANE" Margaret's face is flushed. She gazes at the name... then rushes back to her work area. She manically hunts: Brushe tubes, rags -- and an EXACTO KNIFE. Ah! She runs back to Walter's painting. Heart pounding, s grazes the knife up against the signature, then DIGS. And -- the "W. KEANE" flecks off. Revealing... underneath the name "S. CENIC"

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: She trembles, overcome. Music SWELLS. Her eyes spin back

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF QUICK FLASHBACKS
dialogues.text: Walter painting at the Palace of Fine Arts. His canvas is blank. Walter in the apartment, signing his name to a finished p Walter spattering paint on his clothes. Walter the day we met him. He shows off a rack of finishe paintings at the Sunday Art Show.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON MARGARET
dialogues.text: She collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grandfather clock says 10:15. Margaret sits gloomily, staring at the clock. Clutching a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2:30 a.m. Margaret still stares at the clock. She's stewi Suddenly, keys in the door. Walter swings in, tanked and of life. He skids across the marble, humming to himself - when -- he's startled by his wife. He jerks. 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M-Maggie! What're you doin' up? Margaret glares. Not speaking. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a helluva night. Worked three or four clubs. (he winks, loosey-goosey) Stumbled onto some hot gossip: Madame Chiang Kai-shek is coming to town! Straight from Taipei! I think we should present her with a painting -- get Dick to flack it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the heck with Dick. I met a new guy at UPI...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should give her one of your street scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think? I dunno -- I thought you could whip off a doodle of Chinatown. With a cute little kid, sort of a big- eyed slanty-eyed thing... Margaret's anger is raging. She glares, steely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Walter. She's a dignitary. Doesn't she deserve a piece that comes straight from you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From your experience???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Maybe you're right. She probably doesn't have a Parisian street scene hanging in her palace. Margaret nods, as if they've settled something. She turns walk away -- then suddenly SPINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless Madame Chiang Kai-shek already has a Cenic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He freezes up. Suddenly sober, smacked to reality. 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Cenic"...? Uh, what's that? Margaret stares, eyes sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cenic is the name of the artist who did all your early paintings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huhhh? (spinning his lie) Urgh... oh! CENIC! (he laughs crazily) Cenic was my nickname in Paris! All my art school pals loved my scenic views, so they called me "Scenic"! But since those Frogs can't pronounce a hard "e," I became "Cenic." He looks up at her hopefully. But she shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more you lie, the smaller you seem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unyielding, scrambling) How DARE you accuse me of lying! I'm proud of my early Cenics!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do you paint over the name? Walter gasps, floored. Margaret bores in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit of advice: Don't use a water- base over an oil. It flecks off. Walter cowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound crazy! For God's sake. You've... you've SEEN me paint!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always thought I had... but it's some kind of... mirage. From a distance you look like a painter, but up close... there's nothing there. 69.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: All life drains from his face. His eyes go glazed. He spe mechanically. Tiredly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I studied art in Paris. I went to school at the Beaux-Arts. The Grand Chaumiere. I spent hours in the Louvre, gazing at the greatness of the Masters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter? He turns. She winces, pained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you even been to Paris? Walter blanches. He shakes, broken up. He looks away, then staggers to a chair. He falls into it Trembling. Not able to look her in the eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted... I so wanted to be an artist. But -- it just never turned out good. Margaret stares, seething. Then, without comment, she storms away. She SLAMS the doo shut. BANG! Walter doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret makes Jane breakfast, scrambling up eggs. Jane glances over her shoulder -- and notices Walter in t living room, asleep on the couch. An awkward pause. Jane says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret is making the bed. Straightening the pillows. In the b.g., Walter silently creeps into view. Shamefully standing in the doorway. Not speaking... Margaret knows he's there, but doesn't acknowledge his presence. Finally, without making eye contact -- 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you sleeping in this room any longer. I -- I can't keep living these lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's three extra bedrooms. Go pick one. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret sits, unmoving, trapped in the big house. Outsid JAPANESE GARDENER trims the hedges. Margaret stares at the walls, a smothering Walter Hall of Fame: Framed magazine articles on Walter, smugly posed wi the Waifs. She swallows, then gently opens a dresser drawer. Inside an ORIGINAL WAIF from long ago. A small oil of Jane, when was a toddler. Margaret stares... and then her face slowly crumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret huddles with a SKETCHPAD. Rembrandt is at her fe She's drawing. She looks up, as Walter anxiously enters. He's holding a drink. He clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you working on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new MDH. Something for me. It's about a woman trapped in an uncaring world. I call it, "Escape." Walter bites his lip, afraid to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured out a solution to our problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teach me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me your tricks. Then you can pass off the Waifs, and we won't be lying anymore. She looks up in disbelief. 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then -- YOU'LL paint them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure! Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, this isn't paint-by-numbers! You think it's easy?! It took me years to learn --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-you're right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know me! I'm a quick study. And I've got the basics... He trails off, unsure where this is going. Trying to rouse her, Walter rushes to an easel and throws blank canvas. She eyeballs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you knew the basics, you wouldn't be at the easel. You have to sketch it first! Walter tightens, feeling stupid. He lets go of the canvas Margaret stares, deciding. Then, she tosses him a PAD. Walter catches it. Slowly, he crosses over...

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET AND WALTER
dialogues.text: They peer at each other, like a Mexican standoff. Then, h nervously picks up a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...? What's first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. You tell me. You're the creator. He frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a -- Keane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a Keane! How witty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, when we met all those years ago, I never would've imagined in my wildest dreams that one day -- 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YEAH YEAH! Point taken. I'm standing here naked and humiliated in front of you. Look... can we just do a crying child? She gazes at him. Fingering her pencil... Trying to jump-start things, he starts to draw a circle -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is the subject?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? C'mon, it's a head --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It matters! A young child's head is round. An older child's head is oval! He feels pressured. Hand shaking, he draws a crooked circ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The child is this old!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're trying to make this difficult --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO I'M NOT! Every line is a decision!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's easy to talk about art, but it's not easy to MAKE art!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret easily outlines a head, then two circles for eye Walter tries copying, but his eyes are misshapen. Again, Walter copies, but he's wobbly. Angry, he scratche out. Margaret tries to help, guiding his hand. Insulted, he pu her off. He CRUMPLES the page. NEW TACTIC: Walter grabs her sketch. He puts it on a LIGH TABLE. Despairing, he starts to trace it..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter finally paints. We can't see the canvas, but he's meticulous. His expression quite earnest. He adds a final flourish... and then... a flicker of pride crosses his fa He smiles. 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We slowly MOVE AROUND... to REVEAL HIS PAINTING. And... it's... absolutely dreadful. Kindergarten quality. Walter stares. Then, he furtively glances at Margaret's work. Comparing. The realization slowly sinks in. He has no ability. A sadness swells into fury... and suddenly Walter GRABS H CANVAS and SMASHES IT AGAINST THE EASEL. CRASH!! The canv SHREDS. The frame blasts into pieces! Walter spins. He glares at one of Margaret's finished Waifs... then explodes, even more enraged. HE PICKS UP

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Walter!! Huh? He lurches, startled.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Margaret stares him down. Sweaty, chest heaving, Walter staggers towards her. His f scowls, untamed. He clenches his fist, like he might atta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then -- he SCREAMS and smashes her CANVAS. BAM!!! The painting RIPS apart. Walter KICKS his foot through the remains, then spins and charges from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOURIST FAMILIES mill about. Suddenly the door SLAMS open Walter bolts in, wild-eyed. A bit deranged. The families gawk -- glancing from Walter to his photogra all over: "WALTER KEANE! THE WORLD'S TOP-SELLING ARTIST!" Walter ignores them. He rushes a buxom REDHEADED CLERK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's SALES?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know. Mondays -- Walter MUTTERS strangely. He snatches some paper and star scribbling. Then he runs into the 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter agitatedly paces, circling the stacks of PRINTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many posters are back here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly? I dunno, 3,000 or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the printer owe us more? Do we owe him??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, let me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the OILS?! Are there more at the warehouse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keane, I'd have to make a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the LOVE OF MUD! What am I PAYING you for? The girl freezes, rattled. Walter spins, flipping out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hypothetical question: If you were a man, would you marry Kim Novak or my wife? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay! Different question! If I got crippled and had to stop painting, how long before the gallery ran out of inventory and went belly up??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want a glass of water, Mr. Keane? Walter sighs. His thoughts drift away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it all mean? Why are we put on this earth? A 100 years from now, will people even know we existed...? 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I don't understand. You'll always be famous. You were on the Jack Paar Show... (she glances away) Er, excuse me, sir. The girl hurries away, to ring up some customers. Walter silently watches. At the register, the Tourists bu print. A "Madonna and Child," MDH-style. BAMMM! Walter's eyes bulge, like he's been stung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not even mine! It's one of hers. Aching, he staggers off. Sweating, woozy, he sits at a ta Distracted, he glances down at a newspaper...

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: There's an article on the 1964 NEW YORK WORLD'S FAIR. A headline says "CONSTRUCTION RACES TOWARD APRIL OPENING"

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: His eyes narrow, piqued. World's Fair??? He leans in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A return to the charming bistro Margaret and Walter went all those years ago, on their first date. The Maitre'd BE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Monsieur and Madame Keane! Delighted! Always such an honor! ANGLE on the Keanes. They are sullen. At wit's end.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: They stiffly sit at their old table. He snarls, eyes blac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doesn't change anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to hold her ground) I know the truth. 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares?! This is all your fault! Maybe it's time to shake things up. Start puttin' my name on the MDH's. Margaret is astonished. A fury crosses her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! Absolutely NOT!! I still hate myself for giving you the Waifs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet! Lower your voice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'll talk as LOUD AS I WANT --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO YOU WON'T! Or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have you whacked! She jerks, flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you tell ANYONE, if you squeal, I'll take you out! I -- I know people. Remember Banducci's cousin? The liquor wholesaler? Pause. Margaret breaks into tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're threatening me...?! Fine, kill me! My God, I've kept our secret for years! I've never once --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what it's been like for me? I don't have any friends. I've lied to my own child... Margaret shudders, distraught. Mascara runs down her chee Walter squirms, uneasy with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, wipe your face! You look a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's life imitating art! A crying Keane! He hands her his handkerchief. She dabs at her eyes. A looming quiet. 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, Walter? Everything with you is calculated. We're back where we had our first date... Walter's eyes widen. We MOVE IN TIGHT on them. He drops his voice. Dead seriou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't deny I need you. You're the one with the gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now there's a shot... God, I'm shaking I'm so excited. The New York World's Fair. 70 million visitors. Opening day, I unveil my MASTERPIECE! She is flummoxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What masterpiece?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly! What have I been missing all this time?! Da Vinci has his Mona Lisa... Renoir has his Boatmen's Lunch... but where's my defining statement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound insane. Artists don't announce a masterpiece --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?! Didn't Michelangelo know he was hittin' a homer, when he was on his back painting the Sistine Chapel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He worked on that for FOUR YEARS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Posterity, baby...!! She empties her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here's the best part. It's for Unicef! Unicef is sponsoring the Hall of Education. Aw, we can finally give back to the children of the world!! Margaret stares, wavering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STOCK FOOTAGE: The 1964 WORLD'S FAIR READIES TO OPEN. Men cranes hammer away. Fantastic, futuristic pavilions rise. The Hall of Education gets erected...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - An INSANELY BIG, BLANK CANVAS. It's 8 feet across filling half the room. Margaret is in the throes of hasti creating the MASTERPIECE. Sketches are tacked everywhere. Margaret is chain smoking sleep-deprived. The DESIGN is a staggering multiracial CR of children, mournful, extending to the horizon. Walter enters, silently scrutinizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too big. Why'd you promise them Cinerama size?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it has to encompass all children. All races! One hundred stricken faces! Marching to infinity! The ultimate Walter Keane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least that's what I told Life Magazine. Margaret ignores this. Walter does a rehearsed turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a publisher says it's good timing to put out a coffee table book. You know, classy: "Tomorrow's Masters."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they need my... uh, early portfolio. My artistic evolution... Margaret's eyes pop. That's it. We PUSH IN... as she struggles to contain her frustration. Suddenly -- she SNAPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right! Where are your preliminary sketches?? All that time in art school, and somehow we waylaid your youthful experiments! The half- finished charcoals, the struggles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit off-balance) I know you're being sarcastic, but these are all good ideas. Berlin war orphans... early self-portraits... 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here. I'm trying to work. She brusquely spins away, back to the canvas. He shoots her an uncertain, dirty look. What just happene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teenage Jane wanders through the house. Shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, what's for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom! Are you home...? Nothing. No sign of Margaret. Jane tries the door of the PAINTING ROOM. As always, it's locked. Hm... Jane sneakily glances around. Opportunity. Quickly, she stands on a chair and reaches above the door sill. She feels around... and finds a KEY. Ah! Hurriedly, Jane UNLOCKS the door and lets herself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is a madhouse of WAIFS. Jane takes it all in. He face darkens. Then, heavy breathing. She turns. Margaret is asleep, cur up under the almost-finished Masterpiece. Jane leans in. Slowly, Margaret rouses -- then suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-what are you doing in here --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is -- Walter's studio!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to leave! Jane peers sadly at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom... I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, you don't know anything!! Jane's face tightens. Insulted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a child anymore. 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry, Jane runs out. Margaret stares after her -- comple remorseful. She knows she did the wrong thing. Suddenly, she runs after Jane and grabs her tightly. Overcome, Margaret starts weeping. Jane starts crying too

dialogues.speaker: LIFE MAGAZINE
dialogues.text: A gargantuan spread. The LIFE ARTICLE is titled "The Man Paints Those Big Eyes." We PULL OUT...

dialogues.speaker: INT. NEW YORK TIMES
dialogues.text: Starchy John Canaday reads the article, gaping in utter disbelief. His desk says "JOHN CANADAY, SENIOR ART CRITIC He also has Walter's BOOK, "Tomorrow's Masters Series." W WIDEN, revealing he's in the busy New York Times NEWSROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four... five... SIX pages! Is there something here I'm missing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's like -- the Hula-Hoop! He just won't go away...! He flips a page -- then his jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Will be unveiled in the Grand Pavilion of the Hall of Education... internationally celebrated artist has been selected... will represent the aspirations of children worldwide --"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh this is ABSURD! He GRABS for his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A panel flicks, and the huge empty space lights up. It's overwhelmingly cavernous, a bright, freshly-painted Space spectacular. Up high hangs The Masterpiece and its 100 ki A sign says "TOMORROW FOREVER." Below, two tiny figures walk in: Canaday and an obtuse CI LEADER. Canaday stares up in horror. Utterly stupefied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And WHO was on the selection committee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Well there wasn't a "committee," per se. We just had a luncheon with me, Ed, Jerome, Jerome's wife...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though technically, we didn't invite submissions. Mr. Keane just contacted us directly! Canaday reacts, smoldering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STRING QUARTET PLAYS at a GRAND PARTY. It's completely fabulous -- an old-money mansion filled with stuffy BLUE BLOODS, all tuxes and gowns. In the doorway appear Walter and Margaret. They're dresse kill. Walter's radiant -- but Margaret looks like she's a to emotionally disintegrate. Suddenly, he WHISPERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop. Let us appreciate this moment. This is what we've worked toward our whole lives: Rarified air. Inside this house are the movers and shakers. Kennedys. Rockefellers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until today, we've always been on the outside, looking in. But when we enter... we will belong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was happier selling paintings in the park. He gapes, appalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are one crazy bitch. Walter spins and grandly enters. He grabs two CHAMPAGNES a server.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So maybe you have problems with the choices we made... but -- c'mon! Wednesday, the World's Fair opens. Thursday, our book goes on sale!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday, I file for divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, why are you always so miserable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm gonna enjoy my afternoon! The HOSTESS is a bejeweled dowager. Walter makes a beelin 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Teasdale! Walter Keane. I just want to thank you for hosting this absolutely enchanting soiree. Walter takes the woman's hand. She smiles stiffly, silent horrified. She glances around for help. She catches a SOCIETY MAN's eye, and he hurries over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Keane. Have you seen the Times?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er, no. Honestly, I've been so busy all day preparing for this lovely --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should read the Times. The Man gestures. Perplexed, the Keanes follow him into a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room looks like a hunting lodge. On the desk are all DAILY PAPERS. Walter grabs the NEW YORK TIMES -- then gas

dialogues.speaker: NEW YORK TIMES
dialogues.text: It's open to a reproduction of "Tomorrow Forever," above scathing REVIEW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: stare, then turn pale.

dialogues.speaker: REVIEW
dialogues.text: A BLIZZARD of WORDS assaults us:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Lowest common denominator"

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET AND WALTER'S
dialogues.text: faces drop, terribly hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could anyone... say something so cruel? 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a seething fury) What do YOU care?! That's MY name being dragged through the mud! Walter CRUSHES the newspaper. He spins on the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er... yes. Which is perhaps why it would be best for everybody if you -- Walter STORMS out. The guy futilely chases --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter barrels in. The ROOMFUL OF GUESTS are all staring.

dialogues.speaker: WHO WROTE THIS SHIT
dialogues.text: People cower. Walter scans the crowd... and spots a cluster. Ah-hah! Th is Canaday. Possessed, Walter strides over. Canaday stare defiant. It's tense -- until he clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keane, this is not the venue. Perhaps you'd like to write a letter to the editor. Walter's throat tightens. He steps right into the guy's f Women GASP. Tension bristles -- like a fight's about to e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because people like my work, that means it's automatically bad??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But that doesn't make it art either. Walter shudders. Canaday asserts himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art should elevate -- not pander! Particularly in a Hall of Education!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does a man become a critic --?? Because he can't create! You don't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh! That moldy chestnut --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't interrupt! You don't know what it's like! To put your emotions out there, naked, for the world to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What emotions?! It's synthetic hack work! (he loses it) Your "masterpiece" has an infinity of Keanes -- which just makes it an infinity of kitsch! Crazed, Walter grabs a FORK off the buffet. He lunges, like he's about to STAB Canaday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women SCREAM. A few MUSCULAR MEN start to break through, to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looks around -- then quivers, realizing he's out of contr Shamed, he slowly drops the fork. People breathe a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is mortified. This is all too awful. Silent, she watches Walter back out of the party...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Tomorrow Forever" gets TAKEN DOWN. Burly WORKMEN slide t painting into a huge WOODEN BOX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is dark. Walter is raging, in an alcoholic fury 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with lowest common denominators?! That's what this country was built on!! He KNOCKS over a lamp. Crash!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna sue EVERYBODY! I'll sue that pansy critic! And the World's Fair! And -- Unicef!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! I'll take down Unicef, and all their precious little boxes of dimes! Walter RUSHES BY. In a dim alcove, we make out Margaret a Jane, huddled in the shadows. Jane looks up at her mother with wide, frightened eyes. Suddenly -- Walter LUNGES at them! They SCREAM, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't sue you, can I? (in Margaret's face) You were the ultimate betrayal! You FAILED me with that painting! Suddenly, he pulls out a BOOK OF MATCHES. He lights a MAT and waves it sinisterly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You crossed over from sentimentality to KITSCH! He THROWS the match at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: STOP IT
dialogues.text: He lights ANOTHER MATCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like making me look bad?? You enjoy people laughing at me                         He PUNCHES the wall, then tosses the match. Fwoosh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter! He throws ANOTHER MATCH. 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret grabs Jane and starts running. They rush into the blackness. Walter squints woozily, then starts to CHASE --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies run for their lives. Violent THUDS behind them! Something SMASHES. Margaret reaches the Painting Room. She YANKS Jane inside then SLAMS the door! Walter staggers up.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE PAINTING ROOM
dialogues.text: Margaret LOCKS the door. She backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter tugs the door. He POUNDS it, crazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme in, you BITCHES!!

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE PAINTING ROOM
dialogues.text: Margaret and Jane shudder. All around them, Big Eyes stare down from above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his haze, Walter remembers the hidden key. Raging, he drunkenly pulls over the chair, then stands on it. But he's too wobbly -- and falls. Bam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE PAINTING ROOM
dialogues.text: Margaret hugs Jane. 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, what are we gonna do                         Margaret thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter laughs crazily and lights another MATCH. It flicke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got all that paint and turpentine in there? Well I'm gonna burn you up! He pushes the lit match through the KEYHOLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna blow like an atom bomb!

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE PAINTING ROOM
dialogues.text: The match drops on the floor -- then goes out, harmless. That's it. Margaret makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're leaving. Determined, Margaret runs to the curtained wall. She whip aside -- revealing the sliding glass doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is lighting another match -- when he spins. Throug rheumy eyes, HEADLIGHTS orbit across the front window. He peers, confused...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret and Jane drive fast. Adrenaline pumping. Lights the city flash across their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I wasn't the mother I could have been. I -- I should have done this years ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't even have any clothes! 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we're going, we won't need much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawaii. Jane freezes, not sure whether to believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really...? Margaret smiles softly. We slowly PUSH IN to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Hawaii. Because it's paradise. There's flowers, and birds, and beautiful colors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... we're going to make a new life for ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawaii, paradise indeed. A dense, tropical forest of deep greens and giant blooming flowers. Margaret stands on the porch of her small, lovely house, breathing in the clean air. She looks lightened. In a clearing, Jane plays with some LOCAL TEENS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is simple. In one light-filled corner is an EAS Margaret is painting Nature: Splaying ferns. Wild succule In the window, a BIRD flies by, its plumage a dazzling re Margaret thinks -- then takes out a tube of RED PAINT. Sh starts to apply the vivid color onto her canvas... When -- a RINGING PHONE. Margaret reacts, startled. This is unexpected. And unsettling. It RINGS. RINGS. RINGS. Finally, she hurries to her one telephone, mounted the kitchen wall. She slowly answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Maggie --? She freezes.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER ON THE PHONE
dialogues.text: He is strangely controlled and forboding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, you were sure hard to track down. Thought I might never find you... (a menacing chuckle) I'm a little agitated. I got the strangest papers in the mail today. Margaret tries to stay cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a decree of legal separation. I would appreciate if you signed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you acting too rash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, our marriage is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granted, our romance may have seen its better days. The bloom is off the rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm looking out for both of us. What about Keane Incorporated?! We're a professional couple. Like Roy Rogers and Dale Evans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, I want a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew. It hurts to hear you say those words. Silence. He is feigning "hurt feelings." Struggling for a response. Finally, his thoughts sharpen up, smart and shr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure hate that it's come to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I SUPPOSE I can agree to a split -- as long... as you assign me all rights to every painting ever produced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's the price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?! 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is surprised. Greedy, calculating, he wonders if h can push her further...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh -- okay. And... then, we have to consider future revenue stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, Walter! How much more money do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's -- the marketplace! I gotta stay fresh. Surely you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me out of your life, here's my term: You'll have to paint me 100 more waifs. 100 more Walter Keanes! Margaret's face drops, pained. But she doesn't object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret loads BUNDLED, WRAPPED PAINTINGS into a dusty pi truck. Jane comes running by, barefoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to go into town? I'm stopping by the post office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm gonna surf with the gang. Margaret tightens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friends are a bit... wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loosen up, Mom! You're impossible! You move me all the way to Hawaii. Then I actually make some friends, and all you do is complain about them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you need to make some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-you know I can't have people over to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right! Or they'd see the precious paintings!! 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret has no response. Jane runs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret is alone, pouring a drink. She mixes in some ice then sees something odd.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: Coming down the long driveway are two FIGURES. Two small WOMEN, patiently walking toward the isolated house. Margaret stares, puzzled. The women come closer. They are Asian, dressed in formal dresses. Curious, Margaret creep over, spying on them... They walk up and ring the bell. DING-DONG! An unsure beat then Margaret opens the door. The ladies smile politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. We're visiting everyone in this neighborhood with an important message. No doubt you're busy, so we'll be brief. Huh? Margaret stares at them deadpan, highball in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have something to share with you about the wonderful things that God's Kingdom will do for mankind. Margaret's face darkens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested. She starts to close the door... but they continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean that you are not interested in the Bible, or in religion in general?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in whatever you're selling. The lady glances at Margaret's glass. She smiles gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we're not selling anything. We're just here to share the good news. 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From where I'm standing, I don't see much good anywhere. Just a lot of pride, and thievery, and people treating each other poorly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Exactly! That is the good news! What? Margaret is lost. The ladies grab the opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad things in the world are a sign. They show us that earthly Paradise is at hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what it says in Timothy

(she pulls out a BIBLE and quickly thumbs to a page) "In the last days, critical times hard to deal with will be here. For men will be lovers of themselves. Lovers of money. Self-assuming, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient --"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like my ex-husband. Margaret laughs. Surprised, the women laugh, too. Margaret peers at them. At their Bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three women sit. Margaret gazes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been so long since I've been happy. But, I don't even know why I'm telling you... two complete strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's our mission to comfort those in mourning. Jehovah wants us to help the brokenhearted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're -- Jehovah's Witnesses? 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies nod. Margaret thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've explored so many religions. But they all had their flaws...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they're wrong for you. Read your Bible -- you might be surprised by the answers it gives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, you can't go down a path unless you know, in your heart, it's the right one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how do you know...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because our beliefs are supported by the Scriptures. Jehovah is the God of truth. Beat. Margaret glances over at a half-completed "Keane" on the easel. A strange pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honesty leads to self-respect. A feeling of well-being. Margaret is piqued. Her eyes widen. Like a Keane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret is enthralled, avidly perusing a happy-looking booklet, "The Truth That Leads to Eternal Life."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says here a worshiper of Jehovah must be honest in all things. Jane snorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can't believe you let people in the house. 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing to hide!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It also says no lies. "Speak truth. Let the stealer steal no more." Margaret and Jane lock eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud JAZZ plays. Back home, Walter is living a Man's, Man World. He's partying, drinking and dancing with two cute HIPPIE CHICKS in bikinis. The place is like a WAREHOUSE, Keane PRINTS stacked every

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, this is crazy! All these copies... you're like Warhol!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, Warhol's like me. That fruitfly stole my act! "The Factory"? I had a factory before he had a soup can! The girls scrunch their faces, lost. Then -- DING-DONG! Walter peeks out the window, then grin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! It's my art supplies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, Walter eagerly pries open a GIANT CRATE. He pulls padding. Wadded Honolulu newspapers. Then... a PAINTING. Ah! A new WAIF, surrounded by colorful tropical plants. Walter smiles triumphantly -- until -- his happiness melt into confusion. Then horror. We ZOOM INTO the painting's SIGNATURE. It says "MDH Keane Walter freaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JEHOVAH'S WITNESSES sing a joyous, high-spirited PSAL 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Tremble not before your foe, Let all lovers of truth know! That my reigning Son, Christ Jesus, From the heav'ns has cast the foe. Soon will bind the Devil, Satan, Letting all his victims go!" Margaret and Jane are singing happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret pours her liquor down the sink. Margaret tosses her cigarettes in the trash. Margaret swells, feeling a burst of power. Then a VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: D.J., (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh yeah! We got a special guest today. A world-famous celebrity who just called up and asked to come in..!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angle on BIG LOLO, a gregarious Hawaiian D.J. in headphon D.J. She's malihini! Moved to the islands a couple months ago... so let's give a big aloha to Margaret Keane! He pops in a cart. Canned APPLAUSE plays. We reveal acros from him... Margaret. He grins. D.J. So is it true your husband Walter is the top-selling painter in the world? We SLOWLY PUSH IN to her. Tentative, she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... Big Lolo. Everything you just said is false. Margaret takes a deep breath. Working up her courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One: Walter is no longer my husband. (a long pause) And Two: He's not... a painter. Margaret exhales. The D.J. is confused. He checks his notes. 96.

dialogues.speaker: D.J.
dialogues.text: But, am I... mixed-up? Ain't he the guy who does the crazy eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Though he's been taking credit for ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the only painter in the family. Margaret slowly smiles. And then... a calmness comes over her. Like a cloud has lifted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret and Jane walk away. Jane beams proudly, then giv her mother a warm hug. Then -- LOUD CLICKING:

dialogues.speaker: INT. NEW YORK TIMES
dialogues.text: John Canaday stands over a WIRE SERVICE TELETYPE MACHINE. stares at a printout, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have got to be kidding!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT - The San Francisco Examiner. A small headline says

dialogues.speaker: "EYE DID IT
dialogues.text: We PULL OUT, revealing Dee-Ann. She grins in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick Nolan reads the article -- and SPITS UP his martini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banducci CACKLES, terribly amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruben SHRIEKS at the article.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would WANT credit?! 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits in his favorite haunt, eating lunch and readi NEWSPAPER. Suddenly -- he GASPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy mother of GOD! Walter JERKS UP -- feral -- like an animal sensing danger He whirls and looks around. Paranoia ratcheting. Is everybody staring at him? Walter starts shaking in horror Then -- he jumps and BOLTS OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits with Dick. Walter's desperate, sweaty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret's gone berserk! You gotta help me! I need a story, a wire story -- national! -- to calm things down. Dick peers shrewdly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... Walter. What she has said is pretty inflammatory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's nuts! It doesn't even make sense. When I was studying art at the Beaux Arts in Paris, she was still a kid in Tennessee! Dick reacts. Walter whips out the "Tomorrow's Master's" B

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! These are my early sketches. (he flips pages, like a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?! Berlin orphans, 1946!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... how could she...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly! It's impossible! We didn't meet for another nine years! After she busted her first marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, she busted OUR marriage! Sleeping around with whatever trash she could find!! Dick's head is spinning. 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I, but... why would Maggie do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's unhinged! She left me and moved into the jungle. She fell in with a bunch of religious zealots:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jehovah's Witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't know much about them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! These people are gone! Solid gone! They don't celebrate Christmas, they can't salute the flag... they won't even let Janie go to the prom! Dick is startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret sits with a GROUP of her Witness friends. She is sorrowful. Confused. Clutching ASSORTED NEWSPAPERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made me sound crazy!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just rise above it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how can I?! He claims I copied HIM! That he taught ME how to paint! (reading the NEWSPAPER) "She used a slide projector to trace my work and fill in the colors."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And which part of that is untrue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I finally told the truth, I felt good about myself for the first time in years!! I'm not going to let him take that away. Nobody is sure what to say. Until -- Jane pipes up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Is Jehovah okay with suing??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mighty courtroom steps are SWARMING WITH PEOPLE. It's circus. LOCAL TV NEWS CREWS do standups:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen million dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The art world is abuzz! Is it possible that the decade's top-selling painter can't even paint

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or is Mrs. Keane simply a bitter ex- wife, trying to steal her husband's fame and fortune?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today in Federal Court, lawyers present their opening arguments in the case of Margaret Keane vs. Walter Keane and Gannett Newspapers. A trial that could produce the largest libel and slander award in Hawaiian history. Margaret, Jane, Margaret's LAWYER, and her FRIENDS walk u Margaret glances over -- and spots FEMINIST SUPPORTERS sm at her. They hold up signs: "Stand Up and Be Counted!" Margaret is bewildered. She hurries in.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE CURB
dialogues.text: Walter and a POSSE OF LAWYERS exit a towncar. The REPORTE charge over, as Walter puts on a confident face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keane! Are you at all concerned about the charges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm angry as hell! But I'm lucky to have the mighty Gannett News Company watching my back. I expect to have this whole trial dismissed by noon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truthfully, my only concern is that somebody get this woman some psychiatric care. She needs it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The EIGHT JURORS watch attentively. Walter sits with the table of slick Gannett lawyers. The lead lawyer stands in front of the irritable Chinese JUDGE. 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret Keane is a public figure. And as such, she has to prove that our newspapers published statements, aware of probable falsity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there is no evidence that our editors could have known that the assertions were untrue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We would like to submit 692 articles and interviews in which Mrs. Keane credits Mr. Keane as the painter of the so-called "big eye" children. His Associate hands two massive bound PILES OF NEWSPAPERS MAGAZINES to the BAILIFF. Margaret winces. Walter grins, eating it up. The Judge stares sourly at the piles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many years back do these go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Keane has been making these statements since 1958. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a very strange case. These paintings hang in museums all over the world, attributed to Mr. Keane. And regardless of the truth, Mrs. Keane has contributed immeasurably to the confusion... The Judge stares off... then makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems impossible that Gannett's actions would ever meet the legal standard for libel. So -- the charge against them is dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lawyer smiles, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Your Honor! 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter peers, comprehending... and then, a realization sl kicks in. His face turns to horror. The Lawyer nods humbly, then spins away. He smirks at Wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, Keane.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DEFENSE TABLE
dialogues.text: The ENTIRE LEGAL TEAM jumps up and begins packing their briefcases. Walter sputters in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Good luck"? W-where the hell are you going?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were charged with libel. You're charged with slander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just dance your way out of it. The Lawyers file out, leaving Walter alone at the table. He looks very small and pale. The Judge peers quizzically

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keane, you appear to be without counsel. Would you like a postponement, in order to get your affairs in order? Walter glances over at Margaret. She stifles a laugh. He glares daggers. Then, cocksure, foolhardy, he jumps to feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always taken care of myself, Your Honor. And I don't need a bunch of rent-a-suits to defend my good name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's PROCEED!

dialogues.speaker: WIRE SERVICE TELETYPE MACHINE
dialogues.text: Words type out: "AP - HONOLULU - KEANE TRIAL TAKES STARTL

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER WIRE SERVICE MACHINE
dialogues.text: More words type out: "UPI - HONOLULU - HE'S A PAINTER...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick frantically types at his typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm concerned about my old pal Walter Keane. The Hawaiian heat may have cooked his brain! The only thing he knows about courtrooms and lawyers comes from watching Perry Mason on television!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stands down front. Like a Broadway star, center-st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the sole creator of my art. This is my total life. My contribution to the world --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. KEANE! I've told you, you must ask the witness questions! If you're acting as your own attorney, you cannot make statements at this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Right! Ah, sorry, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to keep this all straight... Walter gathers his thoughts -- then turns to the WITNESS STAND. Sitting in it... is Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Keane. It seems impossible that you'd expect anybody to swallow your fantastic story --

dialogues.speaker: MR. KEANE
dialogues.text: Walter grimaces. He tries again, choosing his words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Keane. You seem like a lucid woman. Reasonably intelligent... So how could you possibly have gone along with such a far-out scheme? 103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We slowly MOVE IN ON MARGARET. This is her moment. And then -- quietly, she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was forced into it. You had -- She stops, bothered by this awkwardness. She looks away f Walter, to the Jury instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had me dominated. He would rant and rave if I didn't do what he wanted. I was afraid. I didn't see any option, so I went along. I felt very bad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a TV lawyer) I want to remind you you are under oath. The Judge SLAMS his fists down, enraged. Walter jumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S-sorry. Margaret turns back to the Jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just gave in. I allowed him to take credit for the big eyes. They reflected all my feelings... and... it was like losing a child...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was weak. I didn't feel I could leave and support myself and my daughter. He said nobody would buy the paintings without his personality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he was right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were very talented at being charming. You were a genius at salesmanship and promotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm! It sounds like you've described two different men. One a sadistic ogre... and the other a delightful bon vivant. Margaret stares him in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's you, Walter. Jekyll and Hyde. 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What an outrageous statement! I demand we strike that from the record!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he SLAMS his fist) Overruled!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she loses her temper) No! You're outrageous! Constantly criticizing! Wearing me down! Saying I'd be "knocked off" if I ever told the truth!! The Jury GASPS. Walter throws out his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your HONOR! I ask for a mistrial! Both Keanes starts QUARRELING. The Judge STANDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEY! This is not a domestic squabble! Or -- maybe it is. But the rest of us have no interest in watching you two go at it. Walter calms himself, contrite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for the emotions. I'm an artist. The Judge stares harshly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACK OF THE COURTROOM
dialogues.text: Two SKETCH ARTISTS are busy, drawing the trial. One guy p the other one, to show off his work. His SKETCH is a typical courtroom drawing, except everyon drawn with big ridiculous Keane eyes. The second guy GIGGLES. His buddy grins, then quickly era the silly eyes before anyone sees it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret is back at the litigant's table, with her lawyer 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stands, at his table. He shouts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call as my witness... Mr. Walter Stanley Keane! A strange beat. The Jurors glance at each other. Walter reacts, like he just heard his name. He strides jauntily over to the witness stand. The BAILIFF gives the Judge a weird look. Then, he pulls a Bible. Walter slaps down his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you swear to the tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God?

dialogues.speaker: YESSS
dialogues.text: Walter bounces out, a bit manic. He runs back to his lawy table, then spins to address the empty witness stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keane. There has been a lot of innuendo and contradictory testimony about the genesis of the "big-eyed waifs." Would you mind clarifying to this court, once and for all, who spawned these paintings? Walter sprints back into the witness stand. He sits, then reacts coyly, as if he's surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why -- I created the children. Walter starts to stand again -- but the Judge SLAMS his b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choreography is not necessary. Just sit down and testify. Oh. Walter sits, then gathers his thoughts... We slowly PUSH IN. He smiles, wistfully...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had a wonderful life. I've been an artist, a world traveler, a friend of untold celebrities... (he gets misty-eyed) But when I look back at it all, when I peer into my heart and define what mattered...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: it is that I was dedicated to the hungry children of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It all began in Berlin. After World War II...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the orphans were clutching the barbed wire. Their bodies lacerated, their fingers scrawny, their eyes big and helpless. Imploring me, begging me... "Do something!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Do something."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and then Miss Joan Crawford walked up to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Kim Novak...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Liberace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Wayne Newton...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Natalie Wood walked up and said, "That is the greatest single painting I have ever seen in my entire life." The Judge is bored out of his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born in a small town. My father made upholstery for the automobile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're done. Walter stops, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-but, I'm not finished --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, you are! (he blows his stack) I cannot stomach one more wild tangent or shaggy dog tale. You're not testifying -- you're filibustering! The Federal Courts are overburdened enough, without your docket-clogging nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can stay here until we grow old and die... but it's obvious that this case boils down to your word versus Mrs. Keane's word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... mistrial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! It's not a mistrial!! In my opinion, there's only one way to clear up this thicket. You are both going to paint. Walter gasps, stunned. All color drains from his face.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Her face lights up. She slowly breaks into a satisfied sm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors SLAM open. The Bailiff leads in a crew of COURT DEPUTIES, all carrying ART SUPPLIES: Easels, brushes, pai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, bring those easels down. Careful, don't bump anything... watch it with those paint cans, I got some newspaper on the floor down front... The Jury is fascinated. Margaret watches, quite eager. In the gallery, Jane grins But Walter is horrified. Trying not to tremble. 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bailiff directs the deputies, setting up TWO EASELS, to back. On each easel is placed a small square canvas. The Judge addresses the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I'm not looking for a masterpiece. I don't know much about these things -- I'm a jurist, not an art critic -- but, is one hour enough? Margaret nods: Sure. Shaking, Walter barely moves his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then. You've both been provided with identical supplies... so -- without any further business... Mrs. Keane, Mr. Keane, the court is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret glances at Walter. What will he do? Walter's face is grimly blank. Margaret proceeds. Slowly, she pushes her chair from the table and rises. Walter doesn't move. Margaret walks over to the closest EASEL, then sits. She on a smock over her checkered dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: crane their necks, intently curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: takes a pencil. She peeks over at Walter -- who's still g to his seat. His face tight, his expression queasy. Stari off to some faraway place. Margaret looks up at the CLOCK. 3:20. Okay then. Totally calm, in a motion she's done so many times, she focuses on the canvas and starts outlining a W Everybody watches. Effortlessly, she pencils the EYES. Th are enormous. The largest orbs she has ever done. 109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
