dialogues.text: looks ill. Wracked with uncertainty. The Judge turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... setting the mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting the... muse to strike...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, your muse has 58 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fills in more detail. Ears... nose... then, little finger clutching a fence. The child is peeking over it, staring right at us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is melting down. In total crisis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: second hand sweeps around. It's 3:34...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: look from Margaret to Walter. Why isn't he moving??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: finishes penciling. She leans back, satisfied with the composition. Then, she reaches for... the PAINT. She unscrews a tube and squirts it on the palette. She re it on her lap and starts mixing a flesh tone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gapes at Walter, befuddled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: feels all eyes on him. He has to do something. Hesitantly, visibly shaking, he rises from the table. Margaret notices this. 110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter braces himself, trying to look confident, then tak step. Suddenly -- he SQUEALS.

dialogues.speaker: OW
dialogues.text: Walter contorts his face in AGONY. He grabs his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keane! Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- it's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah shoot! My old shoulder injury just flared up. I've got a bad muscle -- I've been taking medication for the inflammation... Walter shrugs pathetically --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I don't think I'll be able to paint today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The courtroom reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: peers at Walter, knowingly. She's not surprised. This was his only way out. A look between them -- and then she cocks a half-smile an turns back to the canvas. She squirts out some white oil paint, then begins painting the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sinks down in his chair, beaten. All life gone. He stares at the emerging canvas, eyes wide, and we PUSH WALTER'S FACE. He is witnessing the end of his empire... destruction of everything that makes him who he is. We push in TIGHTER... TIGHTER... until the screen fills w his two eyes. 111.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big. Sad. And filling with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open, and Margaret comes tumbling out, victorio She has WON! She's surrounded by Jane, her friends, and a MOB OF REPOR They all SHOUT: "Mrs. Keane! Margaret! Congratulations!!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you! Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to call the painting? She smiles, clutching the finished Waif.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Exhibit 224." They all ROAR with laughter. A Reporter does a stand-up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jury found in favor of Margaret Keane on all points. She won on charges of defamation, emotional distress, damaged reputation --

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACKGROUND
dialogues.text: Walter drifts out, disheveled and lost. He stares hazily. angrily at the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a group of idiots... a quagmire of incompetence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doesn't change a thing! We slowly PULL AWAY, leaving him tiny in the shot. Forgot

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT MARGARET
dialogues.text: She hugs Jane. The Reporter jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret! Do you feel vindicated by the high award?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... it was never about the money. And honestly -- I doubt Walter will even pay. 112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Reporter chuckles. Margaret turns serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted credit for what I had done. The justice is... I got my art back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
